Going back– amino acids join together to form unique molecules, which can take on different morphological forms, which have different structural and electrochemical properties. Some of these properties allow matter to form complex homeostatic loops, and the matter involved in those loops becomes stable. Stable enough to kick off selection– the amino acids in those loops become more numerous, if only by dint of their longevity. Proteins aggregate into informal clusters, which eventually have enough entropic momentum to develop indentities, types, categories (by laying down DNA). These types eventually learn to be morphologically promiscuous, overloading the DNA with different potentialities. The morphologcal (actually phenotypical) potentiality is expressed in the following ways (at least): – one organism that can survive in different environments (eg. seasons) – a community of organisms that specialise and collaborate – one organism which sequentially passes through radically different forms in order to take best advantage of its environment, passing through eg. developmental, resource-gathering and reproductive stages (just examples, not exhaustive) Some smart-alec realises that instead of using the phenotypical overloading to do different things in parallel or sequence, they can just raft together and do all those different things at the same time, as one increasingly tightly-coupled community. The market for gap junctions explodes.
Next up? information starts to be embedded in other parts of the now-growing tissue. Overloading stacked on overloading. The proteins in the cells walls, first used to exchange matter with the environment, later used for intra-species (and inter-species) signalling, later still repurposed to do the meat of the rafting work, now start to manage the electric potential across the entire tissue. At some point the tissue gets to large and splits in two– no proble good buddy, we go our way, you go yours– oh but now you have a slightly different electrical potential, maybe triggereing a different part of the lifecycle, maybe just a mutation spread laterally through your ranks, and now I think maybe we can help each other cause you are producing way more sugars than you need and I twitch just right to drag us out of this cold patch and into that energy gradient that you can make use of– but the electric signature of the two tissues is different, and you have the beginnings of the full bioelectric self-image, the next level of emergence, the next pattern.
–
Now I could go on talking about the origin of species but that has been done. I could also try and hypothecate on the origin of language,
TODO: try to find some of that literature
but that would be next to useless and anyway, I’ve somehow lost the plot. This was not meant to be a grand description of evolutionary determinism! This was meant to be about somthing else entirely! I must have picked the wrong example to start with.
This was meant to be about how perfectly innocent organisms can accidentally invent something that spells the doom of their peers, as a new phase of life emerges with a new dynamics.
The optimizing pressure is real. I don’t think I am shoe-horning this in here.
Lets look at our story so far–
what happened to the maladaptive proteins, once the homeostatic loops started working in earnest? Well they were consumed of course. What happened to all those random strings of amino acids, the cousins of the string that would eventually form the rhybozyme? Optimized away.
It isn’t always that way. I don’t think the phenotypically monotonous bacteria were eliminated by the more dynamic ones either– why is that? Just that there was so much space and so many resources? Maybe the step-up wasn’t large enough– if it is large enough, then the older forms get wiped out and optimized away, but if now, maybe the increased complexity comes with a cost?
Maybe it is simply the case that the simpler bacteria can do things that the more complex ones can’t, and they live in symbiosis? Particularly with multicellular organisms, they can be seen as something like super-predators, which can only arise in environments where the amount of resources crosses some critical threashold– yes that is it. They need to be able to clump, and if there is not enough they dissolve back down to bacterial. It is a discretizing step– you have to step up in discreet jumps, and there is such a vast space between a jaguar and a stretochoccus that the latter will still thrive in droves in environments where the former stalks.
So sometimes there is a winner-takes-all event and sometimes it is possible to live mutually, operating at such different trophic levels that competition makes no sense.
TODO: read some classic papers about trophic hierarchies
So, the explore exploit story is about the winner-takes-all cases. And identifying winner-takes-alls is crucial for the questions we are dealing with here.



A robotic pipette prepares over a thousand samples per hour, running 24 hours a day. Raw chemicals are pumped into small plastic vials, each one an experiment. Each contains a different mix of volatile chemicals. The majority of them form long chains with interesting electrochemical properties– the chemical composition is created from a distribution centered on the median chemical system on earth, but the distribution is fat-tailed, so they aren’t all long chains, some form large complex molecules with tangled 3d structure, some are almost rigid lattices, slices of doped crystals, small chunks of larger mathematically imperfect repeating objects.
Most of the chemicals seem to do nothing interesting– certain signatures are looked for in the fluid mix. The signatures are targeted at specific intersections of different phase spaces, chose to provide hints at activity along a number of different near-orthogonal directions. They map in some ways to each of the follwoing: matter transport, flow stabilization, catalysis, morphological copying, harmonic resonance and more.
There are already hits, many of the vials are coming up with interesting results. Some structures are morpholocally virulent, their enighbors try to mimic their structure as best they can. When they are surrounded by complimentary structures they form long plaques and aggregates, when surrounded by incompatible ones they seem to organize the other molecules in shells around themselves or force them to attempt to mimic, in clumps and clusters, the shapes that come naturally to them.
Some vials trigger no readings in terms of matter flow or morphology or catalysis, but show a distinct ecological development, certain species dissapearing more rapidly than brownian denaturation would explain, ending up as mixes of a few surviving species and a lot of small molecules– often with a sharp rise or drop in pH. These mixes are studied to find better triggers.

In the lab upstairs, the most virulent molecules, the ones with the most outsized-impact on their environment and their peers, are synthesized in huge numbers and mixed again with semi-random collections of other molecules and some proteins. The mixes are periodically sent to a particle cannon for random snapshot analysis and returned, though the agressive free radicals left over from the passing pulses mean any mix can only get cycled five or six times. The stable morphologies assumed by the proteins are collected and compared to simulation. The simulations are trained further.
Molecules that help the proteins form stable structures with high likelihood are collected and the serum is refined until the novo-proteins are forming a few, highly-stable structures which perform different tasks. Catalysis, matter transport etc. Having starting from such a wide distribution, many of the results are quite for from the protiens found in nature, using different amino acids or different acid families entirely. There are even some successes with molecules that are not simply long chains allowed to fold but large covalent structures.

title: Music-I-Like
text:
I like listening to music. I try to listen widely, but also (somewhat) deeply, getting into niche genres and exploring the landscapes I find there. I had a quite tepid entry into music appreciation, growing up listening to Leonard Cohen, Bob Dylan, the Red Hot Chili Peppers, and whatever happened to be popular at the time among my peers (I’m of the Limp Bizkit generation so you can image what that means).
While I was at university, in my early 20s, my musical horizons were broadened, and continued to broaden throughout my twenties. I started listening more and more widely not only to ‘popular’, contemporary music, but also taking a fairly slow, broad pass through the history of classical music. Below I have summarized some of my listening habits of the past ten years.

Occasionally I want to here some opinions about the music I like. I generally look up whatever album I’m considering on Pitchfork on these occasions.
Other than that, there are two sources I should mention: Piero Scaruffi, a physicist I think? I have no idea how I discovered that list, but I have gotten some good stuff from there.
And finally, Ted Gioia. I am working through that list just now. Having gotten halfway through 2019, I’m realising that I need to start skipping the jazz and the folk singers that he recommends, but there is so much weird and fascinating stuff from all over on those lists that I think he will continue to be a great source for many years to come.

title: Alacritty Ascii
text:
Alacritty is one of the many lovely developer tools that are springing up as the first flush in the Rust revolution. Its a fantastic terminal that I’m sure I will have more to say about in due time.
As noted, I discovered something lovely while transferring some files the other day. I was moving my small film collection (currently stretching to 7 titles: <INSERT FILMS>) from one computer to another, and I just wanted to sanity check that the transfer had succeeded. So I sshed into the machine ssh work and ran vlc -I dummy ~/films/Mullholland\ Dr.mkv.
Imagine my surprise to see the criterion logo appear, animated before me. Here is a nice still from another film to illustrate:
You can also look at a copy-paste of the terminal here to prove that it really is ASCII output.
Zooming out, the resolution becomes better and better (text), but it starts to jitter quite badly at a certain size.
I thought the ssh connection might be a bottleneck, so I went to the computer to try it on one machine. I had that slightly haunted feeling that the magic might disappear, and when I entered the terminal I suddenly wondered >How will I get it to work here? If I run vlc -I dummy ~/filmes/Crash.mkv I’ll just get a window.
but as soon as the thought was there I realised I could just start with ssh localhost. And it worked. I was watching the ‘Universal’ logo barge into my terminal.
But things got even better. I noticed that my keystrokes were even getting sent back to vlc, so I could skip forward, pause and even quit the film (sometimes it gets stuck and I have to killall vlc but so it goes).
After a little sleuthing, I notice that
is interactive, but
is not. What is this dummy terminal doing after all? Well, the vlc wiki has a little info[^vlc dummy], and they nicely point out that keystrokes are sent back. I find the terminology a little odd, since ‘dummy video output’ is just normal video output, but I think they are looking at it from a gui-makers perspective. And this seems to be the key– with the dummy interface, vlc streams the movie to a window. Alacritty is presumably pretending to be a screen or a window of some sort, in order to pass its work to the GPU, so VLC merrily dumps the video stream in there.
What I would love to know, and I might take some time to investigate, is how is Alacritty mapping the video stream to ASCII? And why?
I will leave this story here for now. I have two things in mind: one, to investigate further over at the Alacritty github and two, to have some people round for a film, run it through Alacritty-ASCII and run the audio through a digital soundcard or some synths, and make a little performance. I’ll update if either of these things transpire.
In the meantime, if you want to try it yourself, I have uploaded a slightly rushed video of the effect in action (the size limit on asciinema was not made with 4k ASCII movies in mind, so no hard feelings). Asciinema cast attached1.
And here is a final zoomed in still to admire. In the attached text you can see how much of a difference the color makes, presumably a lot of the 8s have the same foreground and background color.

title: Fergus Fettes
text:
How the Origin of Life Reveals the Deep Logic of All Complex Systems
Many of the biggest mysteries around us share the same underlying question: how does something radically novel emerge and sustain itself—from nothing more than the chaotic mix of simpler elements? The origin of life on Earth is perhaps the purest example of this fascinating puzzle. How did chemistry alone cross the threshold from mere molecules jostling randomly, into organized structures able to grow, replicate, and evolve? Answering this isn’t just fundamental to biology. It could illuminate something universally profound about how complexity arises everywhere: from simple chemical reactions, to ecosystems and societies, to our economy and the technologies it produces.
It’s appealing to suspect life is not a singular special case—that its emergence might be governed by rules or principles common to complex systems in general. If we managed to clearly define these principles, perhaps the logic by which life emerged four billion years ago could also apply to the emergence of intelligence, civilizations, and even new forms of technology or social organization today.
To explore this intriguing possibility, we need to first strip away life’s complicated surface—the vast machinery of modern cells, their genes, proteins, organelles—and look deeper, down to its simplest features. One particularly compelling answer to the riddle of life’s emergence has recently come from the field of non-equilibrium thermodynamics. This field studies how energy flows through physical systems, and how certain structures can spontaneously form and persist through the continuous dissipation of energy. It’s known as dissipative adaptation, developed recently by MIT physicist Jeremy England.
In essence, dissipative adaptation says something simple and elegant: given the right environmental conditions, matter naturally arranges itself into configurations that efficiently capture energy from available sources and dissipate it into their surroundings as heat. Right away we can see the relevance to life’s origins—life as we know it consumes energy-rich molecules or captures energy from sunlight, maintains itself structurally, grows, and becomes more efficient at further energy capture and dissipation. This insight helps shift our thinking away from imagining life as a miraculous anomaly, and instead implies it’s a structured response to steady inputs of energy and collisions of simple building-block molecules.
We can formalize this picture a bit more precisely. Imagine some collection of matter in contact with a steady energy source—a warm geothermal vent, sunlight streaming on a primordial beach, a chemical redox gradient. Its immediate future will depend on a surprisingly simple set of factors:

ΔE (Energy gradient): How accessible and maintainable energy flow is in the environment.
T (Temperature stability): The environment needs temperatures moderate enough (a “Goldilocks range”) to let complex arrangements form without being immediately destroyed.
Z (Chemical diversity): The presence of varied chemical elements and molecules to form the building blocks of more complex structures.
ρ (Density): The density of interactions among these molecules, enabling continuous structural reshuffling and experimentation.

We combine these four key factors into a single, comprehensive measure that captures the environment’s potential for sustaining and evolving complex structures:
[ G_{env} = () S(T) (Z) ]
where: - ( ) measures the available energy gradient per unit of mass—essentially how much energy the system can access. - ( S(T) ) is a function describing how stable molecular structures are in relation to the environmental temperature, sharply declining as temperatures become too high and more gradually declining as temperatures become too cold. - ( (Z) ) is a term quantifying chemical diversity, accounting for the presence of varied building blocks.
This number, (G_{env}), is an environmental upper bound—a measure of how conducive the surroundings are for simple matter to spontaneously self-assemble into organized, complexity-building dissipative structures. High values mean it’s very likely configurations will form spontaneously that efficiently manage these energy flows, continuously experimenting and occasionally stumbling onto configurations that reproduce effectively, or “stick” better in the environment.
But the complexity that emerges isn’t just determined by isolated environmental potential. It also depends historically on what’s come before. This is the idea of accumulated complexity, which we call:
[ G_{cum}(t) = _{0}^{t} G()d ]
Where (G()) represents what fraction of the environmental potential is actually accessed at time (), depending on how organized and sophisticated the previously evolved structure already is.
Initially, if you’re starting simply from elemental chemistry, the fraction of (G_{env}) that can actually be accessed will be very small, because there’s no sophisticated structure yet in place to efficiently harvest most available energy. Over time, though, this fraction increases: complexity emerges as structures build on structures, energy-transducing pathways and storage methods evolve, and chemistry moves from simple molecules to complex autocatalytic cycles, primitive cells, ecosystems, and beyond. At each level, previously accumulated complexity ((G_{cum})) unlocks access to more of the environmental potential ((G_{env})).
This simple but powerful dynamic helps explain why we see complexity arise continuously but unevenly through history. It suggests an accelerating nature to how complex systems evolve: previous complexity constantly unlocks new capability. It also helps explain why complexity can expand surprisingly quickly when it finds itself in new, unexplored niches possessing high environmental potential that are just starting to become accessible—like land when plants first colonized it, or the internet when early computers first came online.
This is only a single step toward a broader goal—a way to unify theories of complexity, energy rate density, thermodynamics, and evolutionary dynamics into one grounded, intuitive framework.
Such a unified theory is ambitious, of course. But consider the power of what it might enable. Rather than viewing research on the origins of life and the evolution of society as separate fields, we could view them as part of a greater exploration into how complexity emerges, sustains, and grows at all scales. Rather than treating biology’s rise from chemistry as detached from the advent of technology and civilization, one theory built on first principles could help us understand both the primordial slime and sophisticated machine intelligence as points along the same continuum.
Suggestively, this continuous viewpoint may even clarify how to drive complexity to beneficial new heights in our own societies—well beyond what we’ve achieved intuitively so far. Then we’d be outlining not just a scientific breakthrough, but perhaps pointing to an entirely new way of understanding and navigating the turbulent waters of the future.
Given all this, let’s begin simply. Dissipative adaptation gives us our first clear insight: complexity’s emergence might indeed be far simpler and more universal than we’ve allowed ourselves to imagine.

title: Fergus Fettes
text:
Title: Beyond the Drake Equation—Charting the Goldilocks Manifold of Complexity
The Drake Equation has long been our go-to framework for guessing how many technological civilizations might exist in the galaxy. But its static, filter-style approach—“fraction of planets that could support life,” “fraction of those that go on to intelligence”—feels out of step with what we now know about evolution and complex systems. Life doesn’t flip on like an interstellar light switch; it grows, adapts, and reshapes its environment over billions of years.
What if instead of binary probabilities, we describe every point in space and time by its intrinsic potential to foster complexity? What if we then track how actual complexity accumulates as matter travels through these “Goldilocks” regions? This is the promise of the Goldilocks Potential framework—a continuous, physically grounded model that unites early universe chemistry, planetary habitability, abiogenesis, and even the rise of AI under one conceptual roof.

The Limits of a Static Equation The Drake Equation asks us to estimate terms like R* (star formation rate), fp (planets per star), and fl (fraction of those planets that develop life). But it tells us nothing about when or how life actually emerges—and it treats each term as a fixed probability rather than a dynamic process evolving through time. As a result, it obscures the very mechanism by which life arises, persists, and diversifies.
Introducing the Goldilocks Potential (G_env) Instead, imagine defining a local property—call it G_env—that measures an environment’s instantaneous capacity to support non-equilibrium, self-organizing structures (i.e. prebiotic chemistry, microbes, ecosystems, or even industrial societies). G_env is an intensive quantity with clear physical inputs:

• ΔE: Available free-energy gradient (solar flux, geothermal heat, chemical redox). • S(T): Temperature-stability factor (0 to 1), peaking where structures persist yet react. • Z: Chemical-diversity factor, quantifying elemental and molecular building blocks. • ρ: Density, ensuring sufficient encounter rates for reactions.
Mathematically:  G_env ≈ (ΔE/ρ) × S(T) × φ(Z) This yields an energy-per-mass potential (J/kg), convertible into a maximum sustainable Energy Rate Density (ERD) over a chemical timescale.

Horizons of Habitability—Cosmic and Local Remarkably, periods when the cosmic microwave background held temperatures between 273–373 K (at redshifts ~100–137) created a universal “habitable zone” for water chemistry— long before stars even formed planets. Today, G_env picks out regions from hydrothermal vents to temperate exoplanets where complex chemistry can flourish. Wherever ΔE, S(T), Z, and ρ align, you trace the Goldilocks manifold—an interconnected network of complexity-friendly pockets across space and time.
From Potential to Reality—Accessible Potential G But raw potential isn’t enough. You need existing complexity to channel those energy flows. Define G(t), the accessible potential, as the fraction of G_env a system can actually exploit given its accumulated sophistication:

 G(t) = G_env(t) × h [ G_cum(t) ] where 0 ≤ h ≤ 1
Here h[G_cum] captures “conditional accessibility”: a newly seeded molecular soup may tap only a sliver of available gradients, whereas a bacterial mat or a human civilization taps them more fully.

Accumulating Complexity—G_cum Actual complexity grows by integrating accessible potential over time:

 G_cum(t) = ∫₀ᵗ G(τ) dτ
G_cum measures the total “work” a system has done to build and export complexity—molecules, cells, soils, technologies. Its growth is non-linear: existing complexity enables more efficient energy harnessing, accelerating further accumulation.

A Worked Example: Ocean vs. Land Imagine early Earth seeded with moderately complex molecules (G_cum₀ = 0.2 in relative units). We compare one cubic meter of ocean water versus bare rock:

• Ocean: ΔE = 1.0, S(T) = 0.95, φ(Z) = 0.80 ⇒ G_env_ocean ≈ 0.76 • Land: ΔE = 1.2, S(T) = 0.50, φ(Z) = 0.10 ⇒ G_env_land ≈ 0.06 • Accessibility h(0.2) ≈ 0.29 ⇒ G_ocean ≈ 0.22, G_land ≈ 0.017
Only the ocean sustains rapid complexity growth. As the marine biosphere produces soil and nutrients, φ(Z)_land rises, G_env_land leaps upward, and terrestrial life “takes off.” This simple sketch shows how G_env, G, and G_cum drive niche opening and complexity expansion.

Implications—Life’s Rarity and Our Future The Goldilocks Potential framework reframes the Fermi paradox: intelligent life arises not everywhere, but only in rare “peaks” of the Goldilocks manifold—regions of sustained high G_env across long trajectories, coupled with enough G_cum to bootstrap further complexity. It also guides search strategies: target exoplanets with high, stable G_env.

On Earth, G_cum has modified G_env itself—soil formation, oxygenation, climate regulation—creating a positive feedback loop that expanded habitability. But we’ve likely not yet reached Earth’s maximum G_env. Extending our reach to moon bases, orbital habitats, and other planets could tap new energy gradients, raising G_env for future generations.

Toward a Unified Narrative of Complexity From the first autocatalytic cycles to neural networks, from hardy extremophiles to language and AI, all complexity is a journey through the Goldilocks manifold. By quantitatively mapping G_env, G, and G_cum, we gain a single cohesive framework—rooted in thermodynamics and information theory—to describe life’s emergence, evolution, and eventual technological ascent.

It’s time to retire static filters and embrace the dynamic, continuous landscape of planetary and cosmic complexity. The Goldilocks Potential offers a rigorous but intuitive compass for navigating the past, present, and future of life in the universe.

title: Towards a Universal Measure of Evolutionary Velocity
text:
Imagine a carbon atom.
This particular atom formed in the heart of a dying star about seven billion years ago. After the star’s violent death, it drifted in interstellar space for millions of years, eventually becoming part of a molecular cloud. Within this cloud, the temperature was low enough to preserve structure but sufficient for occasional interactions. The carbon atom joined with others to form simple organic compounds.
For another billion years, these compounds circulated through regions of varying stability. Sometimes they were bombarded with radiation that broke bonds and created new ones. Other times they drifted through the protective shadow of larger bodies, unchanged for millennia. Occasionally, they passed near enough to stars to be energized without being destroyed.
These organic compounds gradually increased in complexity. Not linearly, but in fits and starts. When they encountered similar compounds, they sometimes combined to form more intricate structures. Some of these structures could catalyze their own reproduction using simpler materials around them.
Eventually, our carbon atom became incorporated into a carbonaceous asteroid. Protected within this rocky shell, it traveled through the young solar system until colliding with the early Earth. Here, in a tidal pool at the edge of a primordial ocean, the carbon atom found itself in an environment unlike any it had experienced before - stable, energy-rich, and teeming with other complex molecules.
Within a few hundred million years, the carbon atom had become part of a self-replicating system that we would recognize as primitive life. The rest, as they say, is history - albeit a history that spans another three and a half billion years.
This carbon atom’s journey is not just a story. It represents a particular trajectory through what we might call the “Goldilocks manifold” of the universe - those regions where the conditions for complexity to emerge and persist are just right.



For decades, we’ve approached questions about life in the universe through the lens of the Drake Equation. While groundbreaking in its time, this approach suffers from a fundamental limitation: it treats evolutionary processes as binary events rather than continuous processes extended through time.
Consider the term fl - “the fraction of planets that could support life that actually develop life at some point.” This formulation obscures the temporal nature of life’s emergence. It’s not simply that life either appears or doesn’t; rather, life emerges at varying rates depending on local conditions.
What we need is a framework that captures this variability in evolutionary velocity across space and time.



I propose that every point in spacetime possesses what we might call a “Goldilocks potential” (G) - a measure of how conducive that region is to the emergence and maintenance of complexity.
This potential can be divided into two components:

G_base(x,y,z,t): The inherent potential of a region based on its physical parameters (temperature, energy availability, stability, etc.)
G_cum(t): The accumulated potential along a particular trajectory through spacetime, representing the complexity that has already emerged and its capacity to generate further complexity

G_base represents possibility; G_cum represents realization.
Temperature plays a crucial role in determining G_base, but in an asymmetric manner. When temperatures fall below optimal levels, G_base declines gradually, approaching zero but rarely becoming strongly negative. Cold preserves information but slows its processing. Structures become “paused” rather than destroyed.
In contrast, when temperatures rise above optimal levels, G_base plummets rapidly, becoming strongly negative. Heat actively destroys information and structure. This fundamental asymmetry shapes the contours of the Goldilocks manifold, creating regions where complexity can persist in “cold storage” versus regions where it is actively erased.



What makes this framework particularly powerful is understanding how G_cum accumulates. The effective Goldilocks potential at any point is not simply the sum of past potentials, but rather:
G_effective(t) = G_base(t) × f(G_cum(t))
Where f represents an exponential or superexponential function. In other words, the capacity to generate new complexity increases with existing complexity. This creates a compounding effect similar to interest on an investment.
This compounding occurs through several mechanisms: - Information storage capacity increases combinatorially with system size - New levels of organization create exponentially more possible configurations - Each evolutionary innovation creates new evolutionary niches - Systems develop meta-learning capabilities that accelerate their own evolution
Recent work in Assembly Theory provides a promising approach to quantifying G_cum. This theory proposes that complex objects can be measured by their “assembly index” - essentially how many steps it would take to build them from simpler components. Crucially, it also considers copy number - how many instances of a complex structure exist in a region.
Using this approach, we could express G_cum as:
G_cum(region) = ∑[MA(i) × log(N(i))]
Where MA(i) is the molecular assembly index of object type i, and N(i) is the copy number of that object in the region.



This framework offers a new perspective on several cosmic questions:
First, regarding the Fermi paradox: We are not necessarily “early” in an absolute sense, but rather in a region that has had an unusually high integrated G value since the beginning. The autocatalytic nature of G_cum creates extreme “complexity gradients” across the universe rather than a smooth distribution.
Second, regarding the origin of life: Life may indeed have origins that stretch back further than Earth itself, with complexity gradually accumulating along cosmic trajectories that eventually intersected with our planet. Earth, with its remarkable stability and energy availability, provided an exceptional G_base value that accelerated the already-present G_cum.
Third, regarding where to look for life: We should focus on regions that not only have suitable conditions now but have had stable trajectories through the Goldilocks manifold over billions of years.



This framework extends naturally beyond biological evolution to technological and cultural evolution. The development of additional information-processing systems - from neural networks to language to computers - represents further acceleration in effective G values.
As Sharov and Gordon noted in their paper on evolutionary complexity, the doubling time for complexity has compressed from billions of years to mere decades. This acceleration follows naturally from our understanding of how G_cum compounds.
The Goldilocks potential framework offers not just a way to think about the past evolution of complexity but also its future trajectory. The regions of highest G_effective are shifting from biological substrates to technological ones, creating new branches in the ancient story of complexity’s journey through the Goldilocks manifold of our universe.
In the end, we are not merely products of Earth’s evolution, but inheritors of a cosmic evolutionary process that has been unfolding since the earliest moments when the universe cooled enough for structure to persist. Our very existence represents one of the highest integrated G values achievable in the 13.8 billion years since the Big Bang - not because we are special, but because we couldn’t exist otherwise.

title: The Goldilocks Potential
text:
I made the mistake of looking too closely at the Drake Equation and now I cant unsee how silly it is. Its full of statements like this: “the average number of planets that can potentially support life per star that has planets”. What?
By contrast, here is a sentence from Hansons ‘Grabby Aliens’ model: ‘“Grabby” aliens is our especially simple model of loud aliens, a model with only 3 free parameters, each of which we can estimate to within a factor of 4 from existing data. That standard hard steps model implies a power law (t/k)n appearance function, with two free parameters k and n, and the last parameter is the expansion speed s.’
Bold. Assertive. Thats how you cut through uncertainty, not hand-waving and hedging. Hanson wins this one, hands down.
But can we do better?

title: The Goldilocks Potential
text:
Accumulated Complexity: G_cum
While G_base describes the instantaneous potential for complexity in an environment, G_cum captures something different: the actual complexity that has accumulated over time along a particular trajectory through spacetime.
G_cum represents history made manifest—the structures, patterns, and information-processing capabilities that have emerged and persisted as matter has moved through regions of varying G_base.
Crucially, G_cum exhibits fundamentally non-linear growth. When a region with existing complexity (G_cum > 0) experiences favorable conditions (G_base > 0), the rate of further complexity accumulation isn’t merely additive but multiplicative:
dG_cum/dt = G_base × f(G_cum)
Where f(G_cum) is an increasing function of existing complexity. This captures a profound truth: complexity begets more complexity at an accelerating rate.

The Mechanism of Accumulation
How does this acceleration happen? The answer lies in the process of selection. In environments with persistent energy flows, structures that better capture and dissipate that energy are statistically favored to emerge and persist—exactly as Jeremy England’s dissipative adaptation framework predicts.
This selection process operates at every scale. Initially, selection might favor simple autocatalytic chemical cycles that efficiently dissipate solar energy or chemical gradients. But once these structures exist, they themselves create new selection pressures and new chemical environments.
The substrate for complexity evolves. What begins as selection acting on simple molecules eventually becomes selection acting on complex molecular assemblies, then primitive cells, then organisms, and eventually ecosystems and societies. Each layer of complexity creates the conditions for the next.
Assembly Theory offers a way to quantify this accumulated complexity through the Assembly Index (AI)—the minimum number of steps required to construct a given structure from simpler building blocks. Recent work shows that under selection pressure, structures with much higher Assembly Indices emerge than would form spontaneously. This is precisely what we observe in G_cum accumulation—selection driving the formation of increasingly complex structures.


Measuring G_cum
We can quantify G_cum in a region by examining the distribution of complexity within it. Using Assembly Theory’s approach, this could take the form:
G_cum = ∑[AI(i) × log(N(i))]
Where: - AI(i) is the Assembly Index of structure type i - N(i) is the number of copies of that structure in the region - The sum is taken over all distinct structure types
This formulation captures both the complexity of individual structures and their abundance, providing a measure of the total accumulated complexity in a system.


The Feedback Between G_base and G_cum
A fascinating consequence of accumulated complexity is that it can modify the effective G_base of an environment. Consider Earth’s atmosphere: the oxygen we breathe wasn’t present in the early Earth but emerged as a byproduct of photosynthetic life. This dramatically changed the local G_base by creating new chemical potentials and energy sources.
This suggests a deeper relationship between our measures:
G_effective = G_base + h(G_cum)
Where h(G_cum) represents the enhancement of effective Goldilocks potential due to accumulated complexity. As complexity accumulates, it can create localized environments with even higher potential for further complexity.
While thermodynamic principles suggest complexity will continue to find pathways to increase energy dissipation, they don’t dictate which specific pathways will be taken. For conscious beings like ourselves, the qualitative differences between possible complexity-increasing trajectories matter enormously. The abstract mathematics of G_base and G_cum must ultimately be expressed through the messy, contingent processes of human society and culture.
