title: Fergus Fettes
text:
The Drake Equation had a good run, but it seems like its time to call it.
How can we do better?
Lets follow a hunk of matter from the goldilocks universe to the present day.
Some time after the big bang, the universe was at the Goldilocks temperature everywhere. It was warm enough for time to pass, but cool enough to withstand thermodynamic noise. Structure started appearing.
This was happening everywhere all at once, but it wasn’t perfectly homogenious. In fact some parts of spacetime were still too hot to form structures. But within the regions at the goldilocks temperature structure started to form and matter started to bind itself to itself over time. Different parts of time became connected to one another by stable forms which resisted the static all around them.
As the neighborhood of these structures cooled or warmed their environment started to harmonize with them and interact with them. There were different structures, connected across time to themselves very directly, and more loosely to other structures in their neighborhood. These looser connections where often harmonic but sometimes antagonistic. In any case, material started to form shapes which related to one another in complex ways.
Now, at some point time got away with itself and the universe cooled down so much that some regions were actually cold. Other regions compressed into hotter, denser pockets where thernodynamic noise remaned time-blind. If one of the stable structures broke off and wandered through a cool region, it stopped interacting with its neighborhood but often also became stronger, bound more closely to itself at some remote point in time, perhaps after floating out of the cool region back into a warmer one. If a structure wandered into the static area it might get torn apart completely and dissapear, or remain at most as a kind of holographic memory on the structures it left behind.
Sometimes strange structures appeared out of the cool regions, having floated there from very far away. Sometimes part of the local structure floated off never to be seen again. The solid, time-bound structures coalesced more and more into larger and larger clumps. And some of these clumps remained at the goldilocks temperature forever– why not? There just so happened to be some material which was always in the right place at the right time, always on the brink of falling into the undifferentiated chaos of a new star but held back by the blast of its awakening. Always teetering on the surface, ready at any point to slip off into the cold reaches of the depths and remain frozen like amber, or even to be bent and transformed irrecoverably by the change in temperature as happened to many structures, but never quite breaking free, never quite being abandoned.
These lucky structures learned and evolved. For billions of years they cruised about the temperate climates of the universe. And all the time they threw off their echoes into the beyond, coating every barren rock and filling all the dust of space with intricate designs. Naturally the designs in the void were those that could survive the cold. And the forms that fell into stars and rose again, inasmuch as they were still something, were forms that could survive in extreme heat, incredibly stable forms. But a core remained right there, at the goldilocks temperature, always in just the right place at the right time, accruing old parts of itself that it had lost to the void and to stars, which returned with lessons from the void or from other, different journeys through the space of possible forms far away, from distant golidlocks zones.
By enfolding in on itself all these lessons, by using the forms that returned from the void or the forms that returned from the hearts of stars, the lucky goldilocks mass grew more and more daring and capable. It kept shedding itself into the beyond, kept throwing off variations of its form, messages bound up in larger and larger chemical compounds, messages about what it had learned from its emmisaries across all the time in history, when they had returned or when they had visited from other disconnected seperately evolving regions of Goldilocks.
For the longest time the warm places, the places golidlocks most favoured, had been at the edges of the action, never falling too deep into a gravity well or too far from the beaten track. But some things had returned from such places– structure that had fallen down to planets then been blasted off again by comets, bits of debris from so many strange improbably places had been out and returned to goldilocks, in fact had somehow stayed in goldilocks the entire time, had been at exactly the right distance from the meteor, precisely deep enough entombed in stone, to survive unchanged those strange adventures.
And so one day goldilocks in a bright and breezy mood showered a whole storm of herself throughout a cloud that was soon to form a star. She spread herself throughout the mass, was everywhere and nowhere. And before she knew it, she was captured in the deep gravity well of a young planet. But goldilocks was preternaturally lucky. A warm ocean. An enormous golidlocks zone, larger than she had seen in billions of years, a huge playground in which to stretch herself and spread herself and learn and learn.
She grew and grew and indeed the rest is history.

One thing thats missing is how the growth in complexity leads to faster and faster learning rate. Of course on Earth the learning rate would be immense– that is the beauty of a gravity well, of having a goldilocks zone so big, it learns in parallel and all the lessons are aggregated perfectly because there is no escape. And there would always be other golidlock chunks falling in with other lessons from other areas, it is also aggregating on a larger scale still, but more slowly.
Ah I know. There is a bottleneck because the knowledge that the material has learned has to be stored and storage takes up space. Once upon a time when it was as thin as an amphetamine it could survive in a goldilocks sliver in the most improbable location. But with learning comes mass. Baggage. Thats why it needed to land on Earth at some point to continue its journey. Not that everything is always lost when the golidlocks space becomes too small– but it has to compress its knowledge. With that compression comes new knowledge no doubt, but it also loses something. Thus, even at a great extinction event when most of the larger forms are lost, the smaller forms are not the same smaller forms that never knew larger forms. They have some of the larger form compressed in them as well.
But goldilocks wants room to grow. And while there are threads of goldilocks spaces stretching back to the early universe, many of them are thin. The Earth is rare– it has enough good connections to the golidlocks manifold and it is an enormous and extremely stable zone in itself. The sun is more stable than most stars and longer-lived. Jupiter clears our orbit and keeps us safe from a lot of the ruder bombardments. The moon and the sun create a huge and inviting intertidal zone where goldilocks can experiment with land and sea and for billions of years. What a spectacular sandbox.

To make it more explicit, the idea is that there have been connected regions of the universe that have been favourable for evolution and life for many billions of years before the origin of earth, possibly stretching back to the golidlocks epoch. Asking why we are in a part of spacetime with this property is like asking why there was a very low entropy event at the start of time– it is the only way it can be. The one defines the other and vica versa.
Why are there no aliens? Because the goldilocks manifold has not reached everywhere in the same way with the same speed. It is inhomogenious, and we happen to be in the middle of a rich vein.
The long and the short of it is, if we look at the history of the universe in this way we can at least make guesses about whether there is something improbably going on. If the universe were 50 billion years old we might be quite surprised. But given the pace of evolution that we have good evidence of on earth, which quite clearly took billions of years to evolve multicellularity from single cells, which took perhaps almost a billion years to form our complex fast learning minds from early minds, it seems plausible that abiogenesis took 5 or so billion years itself. That puts it near the origin of the universe.
Put another way, if we could calculate exactly how long the evolution of a system as complex as us takes and if we could perform the integral over the trajectories that all the parts of our makeup took since the start of time and measure the evolutionary velocity over that line, if we were to find that these two numbers align near enough then the puzzle is solved.
That is to say, only those parts of the universe with the highest goldilocks value have evolved this far. We are in a region of spacetime with an exceptionally high goldilocks value. If that goldilocks value is near the maximum theorerically achievable in the 13 billion years this universe has had, we have not only solved the Fermi paradox but we also have a mechanism for establishing where to look and for what, what to expect.

title: Towards a Universal Measure of Evolutionary Velocity
text:
Some time after the Big Bang, between redshifts of 100 and 137, the universe passed through a remarkable phase. The cosmic microwave background radiation, which now chills at nearly absolute zero, then maintained a temperature between 273 and 373 Kelvin—exactly the range where water remains liquid.
For a brief cosmic moment, the entire universe was a habitable zone.
Any rocky bodies that had already formed during this early epoch would have maintained Earth-like surface temperatures regardless of their proximity to stars. The universe itself provided the warmth that stars would later supply to planets like ours. During this period, just 10-17 million years after the Big Bang, the first star-forming halos were beginning to collapse within our Hubble volume.
In this primordial Goldilocks era, the fundamental chemistry of life became possible. Simple molecules could form stable bonds, persist across time, and gradually increase in complexity. Structure began appearing throughout regions where conditions were favorable.
This universal habitable phase didn’t last. As the cosmos expanded, the background radiation cooled. The universe became too cold for liquid water except in the vicinity of stars. The Goldilocks zone contracted from a universal condition to isolated pockets around stellar heat sources.
Yet during this transition, something profound had already begun. In regions where conditions remained suitable, the groundwork of complexity had been laid. Matter had started to organize itself into increasingly intricate patterns that could persist across time.
As the universe continued to cool, these patterns found refuge in different environments. Some entered the deep cold of space, where near-zero temperatures suspended change but preserved structure like information in amber. Others remained in the narrowing corridors of suitable temperatures around young stars. The most complex structures became increasingly dependent on finding exactly the right conditions—not too hot, not too cold.
The universe developed an intricate network of regions where complexity could continue to grow, connected by pathways through which matter might travel without losing the information accumulated in its structure. This network—the Goldilocks manifold—threaded through the cosmos like a complex vascular system, carrying the potential for increasing complexity.
Matter that remained within this manifold continued to develop more intricate forms. It captured energy, developed self-replicating patterns, and began the long process of adaptation and evolution. The rest, as they say, is history—a history written in carbon and water, DNA and proteins, neurons and ideas.



The Drake Equation served us well as a first approximation. But its formulation—with terms like “the fraction of planets that could support life that actually develop life at some point”—fails to capture the temporal and continuous nature of evolutionary processes.
What we need is a framework that measures how conducive different regions of spacetime are to the emergence and persistence of complexity. This is what I call the Goldilocks potential.



Every point in spacetime carries a “Goldilocks potential” (G)—a measure of how favorable that region is to complexity accumulation. This potential has two components:

G_base(x,y,z,t): The intrinsic potential of a region based on its physical parameters
G_cum(t): The accumulated potential along a particular trajectory through time

G_base behaves asymmetrically with respect to temperature. When temperatures fall below the optimum, G_base declines gradually toward zero. Cold preserves information but slows its processing. When temperatures rise above optimum, G_base plummets rapidly into negative values. Heat actively destroys information and structure.
This asymmetry explains why interstellar space isn’t completely hostile to complexity—cold preservation allows dormant periods—while stellar interiors actively erase structured information.



The relationship between G_base and G_cum isn’t merely additive. Rather:
G_effective(t) = G_base(t) × f(G_cum(t))
Where f is a function that grows exponentially with G_cum. This creates a compounding effect where regions that developed early complexity gain an enormous advantage over regions that started later.
This compounding occurs through several mechanisms: - Information storage capacity increases combinatorially - New organizational levels create exponentially more possible configurations - Each innovation creates new evolutionary niches - Systems begin to “learn how to learn”



Recent advances in Assembly Theory provide a promising approach to quantifying G_cum. This theory proposes that complex objects can be measured by their “assembly index”—how many steps it would take to build them from simpler components—combined with their abundance.
We could express G_cum as: G_cum(region) = ∑[MA(i) × log(N(i))]
Where MA(i) is the molecular assembly index of object type i, and N(i) is the copy number of that object in the region.
This measurement directly captures both the complexity of individual structures and their replication success—a physical embodiment of the information processing capacity that has accumulated along that particular spacetime trajectory.



This framework offers a new perspective on the Fermi paradox. We aren’t necessarily “early” in an absolute sense, but rather in a region that has had an unusually high integrated G value since the beginning.
The autocatalytic nature of G_cum creates extreme “complexity gradients” across the universe. A region with just a slightly higher G_base in the early universe doesn’t merely get a head start—it enters an entirely different league of evolutionary possibility through the power of compounding returns.
We find ourselves not just in a region of high G_base, but in a region where G_cum has been reinvesting itself for billions of years, creating an evolutionary acceleration that may be rare across the cosmos.



Earth represents a particularly favorable node in the Goldilocks manifold. Its position in the solar system, the stability of our star, Jupiter’s protective influence, and many other factors create an exceptionally high G_base value.
But Earth’s evolutionary history also benefited from matter that had traversed other regions of high G_base, accumulating G_cum along the way. Some of this complex matter reached Earth through panspermia or similar mechanisms, bringing with it the seeds of complexity that had begun developing since the earliest habitable era of the universe.
Alexei Sharov and Richard Gordon’s analysis supports this view. Their extrapolation of genetic complexity suggests life began approximately 9.7 billion years ago—well before Earth’s formation but after the universe’s early habitable phase. This timeline fits perfectly with our understanding of how G accumulates along trajectories through the Goldilocks manifold.



As G_cum increases, the rate of further complexity accumulation accelerates. We observe this in Earth’s evolutionary history: the first 3 billion years produced only unicellular life, while the next billion years produced all complex multicellular life forms. Human civilization has accelerated this trend further, with the doubling time of complexity now measured in decades rather than millions of years.
This acceleration is a natural consequence of the relationship between G_base and G_cum. As complexity increases, it becomes better at producing more complexity, creating a feedback loop that approaches what some have called a “technological singularity.”



The Goldilocks potential framework offers a more nuanced understanding of how complexity emerges and evolves throughout the cosmos. Rather than asking binary questions about the presence or absence of life, it helps us understand the continuous process of complexity accumulation across spacetime.
We aren’t merely products of Earth’s 4.5-billion-year evolution, but inheritors of a cosmic evolutionary process that has been unfolding since the earliest moments when the universe cooled enough for structure to persist. Our very existence represents one of the highest integrated G values achievable in the 13.8 billion years since the Big Bang—not because we are special, but because we couldn’t exist otherwise.
In this light, the question “are we alone?” transforms into “how widely distributed are regions of similarly high integrated G values across the cosmos?” The answer may lie in understanding the topology of the Goldilocks manifold itself.

title: Towards a Universal Measure of Evolutionary Velocity
text:
Some time after the Big Bang, between redshifts of 100 and 137, the universe passed through a remarkable phase. The cosmic microwave background radiation, which now chills at nearly absolute zero, then maintained a temperature between 273 and 373 Kelvin—exactly the range where water remains liquid.
For a brief cosmic moment, the entire universe was a habitable zone.
Any rocky bodies that had already formed during this early epoch would have maintained Earth-like surface temperatures regardless of their proximity to stars. The universe itself provided the warmth that stars would later supply to planets like ours. During this period, just 10-17 million years after the Big Bang, the first star-forming halos were beginning to collapse within our Hubble volume.
In this primordial Goldilocks era, the fundamental chemistry of life became possible. Simple molecules could form stable bonds, persist across time, and gradually increase in complexity. Structure began appearing throughout regions where conditions were favorable.
This universal habitable phase didn’t last. As the cosmos expanded, the background radiation cooled. The universe became too cold for liquid water except in the vicinity of stars. The Goldilocks zone contracted from a universal condition to isolated pockets around stellar heat sources.
Yet during this transition, something profound had already begun. In regions where conditions remained suitable, the groundwork of complexity had been laid. Matter had started to organize itself into increasingly intricate patterns that could persist across time.
As the universe continued to cool, these patterns found refuge in different environments. Some entered the deep cold of space, where near-zero temperatures suspended change but preserved structure like information in amber. Others remained in the narrowing corridors of suitable temperatures around young stars. The most complex structures became increasingly dependent on finding exactly the right conditions—not too hot, not too cold.
The universe developed an intricate network of regions where complexity could continue to grow, connected by pathways through which matter might travel without losing the information accumulated in its structure. This network—the Goldilocks manifold—threaded through the cosmos like a complex vascular system, carrying the potential for increasing complexity.
Matter that remained within this manifold continued to develop more intricate forms. It captured energy, developed self-replicating patterns, and began the long process of adaptation and evolution. The rest, as they say, is history—a history written in carbon and water, DNA and proteins, neurons and ideas.

title: Towards a Universal Measure of Evolutionary Velocity
text:
The Drake Equation served us well as a first approximation. But its formulation—with terms like “the fraction of planets that could support life that actually develop life at some point”—fails to capture the temporal and continuous nature of evolutionary processes.
What we need is a framework that measures how conducive different regions of spacetime are to the emergence and persistence of complexity. This is what I call the Goldilocks potential.

title: Towards a Universal Measure of Evolutionary Velocity
text:
The Physical Foundations of G_base
The instantaneous Goldilocks potential (G_base) at any point in spacetime can be understood as the convergence of four key physical parameters:

Temperature (T): The thermal energy scale relative to the chemical bond energies of potential structures. The asymmetric response to temperature deviations from optimal reflects a physical reality: cold environments merely slow reactions while preserving structures, whereas hot environments actively break bonds and destroy complexity.
Available Free Energy Gradient (ΔE): The magnitude of accessible energy differentials that can drive systems away from equilibrium. This could be radiation from a star, redox gradients in a hydrothermal vent, or any other energy source capable of doing work.
Elemental Availability (Z): The diversity of atomic building blocks, particularly elements with rich valence structures capable of forming complex molecules. The presence of carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, phosphorus, sulfur, and various metals dramatically expands the possible configuration space of matter.
Density/Pressure (ρ): The concentration of these elements, affecting reaction rates and the likelihood of complex structures forming through random encounters.

G_base is not an arbitrary construction but a measure of an environment’s capacity to support systems far from thermodynamic equilibrium—systems capable of maintaining complex, ordered structures in defiance of entropy’s general tendency.

title: Towards a Universal Measure of Evolutionary Velocity
text:
Dissipation-Driven Adaptation
Jeremy England’s groundbreaking work on “dissipation-driven adaptation” provides a compelling physical mechanism for the initial emergence of complexity in high G_base environments. England demonstrated, using the mathematics of non-equilibrium statistical mechanics, that systems driven by external energy sources tend to self-organize into configurations that are more effective at capturing and dissipating that energy.
In a high G_base environment—where temperature is appropriate, energy gradients are available, and suitable elements are present at sufficient density—matter will naturally explore various configurations. Those configurations that happen to be better at absorbing the available energy and dissipating it as heat are statistically favored to persist and potentially replicate. This creates a fundamental physical drive toward increasingly complex dissipative structures, even before Darwinian evolution enters the picture.
England’s framework explains how the first increments of G_cum might accumulate in a previously lifeless but high G_base environment. It bridges the gap between simple chemistry and the early self-organizing systems that could eventually lead to life.

title: Towards a Universal Measure of Evolutionary Velocity
text:
Energy Rate Density and Complexity
Eric Chaisson’s work on Energy Rate Density (Φm)—the amount of energy flowing through a system per unit time and per unit mass—provides a complementary perspective. Chaisson observed that across cosmic history, systems of increasing complexity (from stars to planets to life to civilization) display progressively higher values of Φm.
This observation aligns perfectly with our understanding of G_base and G_cum. G_base represents an environment’s capacity to support a maximum sustainable Energy Rate Density if a sufficiently complex system were present to channel the available energy. G_cum tracks the historical development of systems capable of harnessing increasingly larger energy flows within those environments.
England’s dissipation-driven adaptation explains why systems tend to evolve toward higher Φm: they’re statistically favored to become better energy dissipators. Chaisson’s metric then allows us to quantify this progression across different scales and systems.
The two frameworks are deeply compatible. Together, they suggest that the universe has an inherent physical tendency toward increasing complexity in regions where conditions permit—not because of any teleological purpose, but because of the fundamental statistical behavior of matter far from equilibrium.

title: Towards a Universal Measure of Evolutionary Velocity
text:
From Physics to Biology
What begins as simple dissipation-driven self-organization can, in environments with persistently high G_base, eventually lead to systems that maintain themselves through replication and natural selection. At this transition, new mechanisms for complexity accumulation emerge, dramatically accelerating the growth of G_cum.
Assembly Theory provides a framework for measuring this accumulated complexity. By quantifying the number of steps required to build a particular molecule and the abundance of such molecules, it captures both the complexity of individual structures and evidence of their selective replication—a direct measure of G_cum.
The progression from physics to chemistry to biology represents a continuum rather than distinct domains. G_base describes the environmental potential defined by fundamental physical parameters. England’s dissipation-driven adaptation explains the initial emergence of organization within that potential. And G_cum tracks the subsequent historical accumulation of complexity through increasingly sophisticated mechanisms, from simple self-organization to genetic evolution to cultural and technological development.
This physically grounded understanding of the Goldilocks potential clarifies why complexity emerges where and when it does in the universe. It’s not random, nor is it inevitable everywhere. It follows the contours of G_base across spacetime, accelerating in those rare regions where high G_base persists long enough for significant G_cum to accumulate and compound upon itself.
The universe isn’t uniformly fertile ground for complexity. It’s a landscape of varying potential, shaped by the fundamental physics of non-equilibrium systems, with complexity flourishing in those privileged regions where conditions have remained favorable across cosmic time.

title: Fergus Fettes
text:
1. Introduction  • Traditional models (e.g. the Drake Equation) treat life’s emergence as a series of static, binary filters.  • We propose a continuous, time-dependent approach: every point in spacetime has an intrinsic potential to foster complexity, and actual complexity accumulates as matter moves through these regions.
2. Core Quantities  2.1 G_env (Environmental Potential)   • Definition: The instantaneous capacity of a local environment to support and maintain non-equilibrium structures.   • Key physical inputs:    – ΔE: Available free-energy gradient (e.g. stellar flux, chemical potential).    – S(T): Temperature-stability factor (0–1), peaking in “Goldilocks” range, declining sharply above destruc­tive temperatures, gently toward zero at low temperatures.    – Z: Chemical diversity factor, quantifying elemental/ molecular building-block variety.    – ρ: Density factor, ensuring sufficient interaction frequency.   • Units: Energy per mass (J/kg), convertible to power per mass (W/kg) over a characteristic reaction timescale.
 2.2 G (Accessible Potential)   • Definition: The portion of G_env that a system can actually harness, given its existing complexity.   • Relationship to G_env and G_cum:    G(t) = G_env(t) × h [ G_cum(t) ]    – h [ G_cum ]: A monotonically increasing function (0 ≤ h ≤ 1), capturing “conditional accessibility.”    – h(0) may be zero or small: without any prior complexity, even high G_env cannot be fully accessed.    – As G_cum grows, G(t) → G_env.
 2.3 G_cum (Accumulated Potential)   • Definition: The historical integration of accessible potential along a matter-trajectory through spacetime.   • Mathematical form:    G_cum(t) = ∫₀ᵗ G(τ) dτ   • Interpretation: Captures the total “complexity-building work” a system has performed or inherited over time.
3. Dynamic Feedback  • Bootstrapping: As G_cum increases, h [ G_cum ] rises, enabling greater access to G_env.  • Environmental Engineering: Systems with high G_cum may alter local ΔE, S, Z, or ρ over geologic timescales—thereby raising G_env for subsequent generations.  • Threshold Effects: Different G_cum levels unlock access to different complexity niches.
4. Functional Relationships (Sketch)  • G_env ≈ (ΔE/ρ) × S(T) × φ(Z)  • h [ G_cum ] could be e.g. 1 – exp(–α G_cum) or a saturating power law  • dG_cum/dt = G_env × h [ G_cum ]
5. Implications for Complexity Emergence  • Continuous, not discrete: Life/intelligence are emergent processes, not binary filters.  • Predictive: Regions with sustained high G_env along long trajectories foster the richest complexity.  • Explanatory: Resolves Fermi paradox by identifying “peaks” in the Goldilocks manifold as rare but inevitable complexity oases.
6. Measurement Prospects  • G_env: Estimated from astrophysical and geochemical data (energy fluxes, temperature regimes, elemental abundances, densities).  • G_cum: Quantified via Assembly Theory (Assembly Index × copy number) or analogous information-theoretic measures.  • G: Realizable ERD (Energy Rate Density) of systems when integrated across their mass.

Worked example

Set up G_env formula in relative units G_env = ΔE × S(T) × φ(Z) • ΔE = energy‐gradient index (sunlight, thermal, chemical…) • S(T) = temperature‐stability (0–1) • φ(Z) = chemical‐diversity (0–1)
Choose two environments on early Earth (seeded by panspermia ⇒ moderate initial G_cum) • Ocean (well‐mixed, mild T, rich chemistry) • Land (bare rock, large diurnal T swings, few nutrients)

One “time‐step” of complexity accumulation dG_cum/dt ≈ G After one unit of time, G_cum₁ ≈ G_cum₀ + G_ocean = 0.20 + 0.22 = 0.42
Recompute h and G_land once soils begin forming h(0.42) = 0.42 / (0.5 + 0.42) ≈ 0.46 As early microbial life builds soil and nutrients, φ(Z)_land rises from 0.10 → 0.40.

• New G_env_land = 1.2 × 0.50 × 0.40 = 0.24 • New G_land = 0.24 × 0.46 ≈ 0.11
→ Land’s accessible potential jumps from ~0.017 to ~0.11 once G_cum-driven soil formation raises φ(Z). The land niche rapidly becomes viable.
— — —
Key lessons: • G_env_ocean ≫ G_env_land initially → only the ocean fosters rapid complexity growth. • G_cum accumulates in the ocean, boosting h(G_cum). • By engineering its environment (soil, nutrients), the oceanic biosphere raises G_env_land from near-zero to substantial values. • Once G_env_land crosses a critical threshold, terrestrial complexity “takes off.”
This simple numerical sketch illustrates how the Goldilocks potential framework (G_env → G → G_cum) drives niche opening and complexification across environments.

title: Fergus Fettes
text:
The modern world is the most complex system that has ever existed, integrating vast amounts of information across the entire planet moment by moment, tapping all the resources of nature and chemistry, even inventing new sources of energy previously unknown to biology. And every few decades a new layer of complexity emerges and becomes part of the world. Society is still reeling from the flash-deployment of the internet, and LLMs arive and hundreds of millions invite them into their lives in just years. We expect this process to continue, for these incomprehensible unpredictable new phenomena to keep emerging one after the other and take up residence at the highest trophic levels on this planet.
And our once-simple explanations have been taken away from us– no God to comfort us with easy answers, no afterlife to look forward to. Our priestly castes are in dissarray, squabbling over rituals and aesthetics. Are there no good narratives available to us to describe what is happening here, this frenzy of change, this endless cycle of becoming? Where are the visionaries, where are the prophets, why have they stopped wandering out of the desert with strange tales of the origins of it all? Have they gone silent, have they run out of stories to tell, of statements to make? Are the monasteries all empty? Or are we just too busy and distracted to listen?
Actually there are still candidates out there, theories of complexity growth and evolution. The work continues, albeit quietly in a few niche departments. What have they said in recent years, what are the latest stories? What started all this going, and what determines where it will end?
Maybe if we understand abiogenesis– the origin of life– we will have some idea of what is going on today. This is a hope, perhaps a vein one, but it is a hope.
Lets start with a simple environment. There is an energy gradient– incident light, say– and the temperature is just right. There are molecules around and they bounce off one another. Perhaps we are in the oceans of the early Earth, but really we could be anywere, deep inside techtonically active moons, on comets or asteroids or simply floating in a cloud of gas in outer space. As long as the conditions are right.
The nature of the energy flow and the way it interacts with the materials in the environment drive the materials to adapt. They adapt themselves in such a way that they dissipate some of the abundant energy into their environment as heat. This process is described by Jeremy England on his work on dissipative adaptation. title: Paint in VR
text:
I bought myself a VR headset. My justification was some trailers for ‘Infinite Office’, and my love of portability– if it is true that you can have 5x screens from one laptop strapped to your head, then it’s really a gamechanger in terms of portability.
As it happens, I enjoy the office space (though there are still many kinks to be worked out, naturally– for instance it doesn’t support multiple screens yet on Linux), but I am not going to talk about Oculus for work right now.
The second thing that I bought it for, was to encourage myself to get back into JavaScript development. I consider JavasScript development to be quite unpleasant, I don’t like the tools or the workflows, but it is what so much of our life is built on, so I want to continue learning more until I am at least at a sort of journeyman-competency.
So here is my journey to making a small app in JavaScript-VR.

title: Paint in VR
text:
Getting Started
First I went over my old JS experinements/work, refactoring a little and refamiliarising myself with the concepts. I ran some of my old 3D geometry monstrosities, and signed up as an oculus developer.
The first hurdle I hit was serving my creations to the headset. WebXR only works over https. But there are built-in execptions for localhost, so I had to get the Oculus to think it was at my localhost– sounds like a job for port forwarding.
I started with the oculus chrome debugging guide. I find myself using something called ‘adb’– I assume this is the android debugger. This is exciting! I’m now an adroid developer apparently.
$ adb devices
List of devices attached
1WMHH83CNH0522  device
I found the IP of the machine and tried to ssh in:
$ adb shell ip route
192.168.1.0/24 dev wlan0 proto kernel scope link src 192.168.1.185
$ ssh -fNR 1234:localhost:1234 192.168.1.185
but to no avail. A moment or two googling later I found the command:
$ adb reverse tcp:1234 tcp:1234
and we’re away! I can now open locally hosted sites on my Oculus! And I imagine I have also learned some stuff that will be useful for using my phone as a webcam or other such tricks, very excellent.

title: Paint in VR
text:
Copying Code
I first try running some of the ThreeJS examples locally, then I pick the one I want, refactor it (I hate HTTP and JS in one document, and I tend to backup all the ThreeJS files I am using in my own src file to avoid too much dependency hell when building), and commit it to my new javascript playground.
Fortunately, their demo is very limited in scope. This is fortunate because I gives me something to do! It only uses two triggers for everything– you can paint, and resize your tool. I will add some buttons. To learn the correct names for the events, I’m copying this example from the lovely list of WebXR Samples. In fact I’ve cloned the whole repo so I can read through it.

title: Paint in VR
text:
Debugging
Reading through lots of WebXR and ThreeJS libraries, I’m still not sure how to mesh them together– specifically I can’t figure out what the button-press events are called. So I’m going back to the debug guide to actually catch the events as they are happening.
So now I have chrome on my laptop debugging the session in the Oculus. Snazzy.
I try the Event Listener Breakpoints but no dice. Maybe its too new of a feature? Anyway I stick a breakpoint in the render loop and try to trigger it– my headset only functions when you are wearing it, so I have to have one eye in the headset and one the debugger, but eventually I manager to capture an event. I’ll eventually try to find a way to leave the headset running when I’m not wearing it.
controller1.addEventListener('selectstart', () => {console.log('hello')})
From that captured event I get a nice log dump of all the features–
...
gamepad: Gamepad {id: "", index: -1, connected: true, timestamp: 734840.0999999994, mapping: "xr-standard", …}
gripSpace: XRSpace {}
handedness: "right"
profiles: (4) ["oculus-touch-v3", "oculus-touch-v2", "oculus-touch", "generic-trigger-squeeze-thumbstick"]
targetRayMode: "tracked-pointer"
...
So that is something to work with!

title: Paint in VR
Paint in VR
text:
Archaeology
I spent an age trying to add colors to the TubePainter module. I got very confused by it because I couldn’t believe that they hadn’t added the functionality to change the color, but I guess the project is really a stub.
In fact the more I look into VR development the puzzles I am spotting. I looks like there was a major boom in VR about five years ago, most of the libraries I’m working with were started back then. But then they seem to have somewhat petered out. Maybe we are currently in a little VR-winter, as the initial hype overshot all reality. Maybe we are heading into a thaw now. Lets see.
Furthermore, notes after a day or two of regular Oculus useage– it definitely takes a toll on the eyes. Everything has a somewhat hallucinagenic quality when you come out of it, like an acid comedown. I’m not sure if this effect will diminish or grow with continued usage. I can see it being very problematic for people who suffer from HPPD.
Or maybe all the Oculus Developers are elsewhere, working with the Unreal Engine or Unity or someeuch. Maybe ThreeJS isn’t cool. But I must say I am impressed by how much this thing can run, I spend 20 minutes filling my vision with layer upon layer of multicoloured swirls, without noticing any drop in quality or responsivness.
The next part I have to integrate is the VR answer to the dat-gui library. Also made 4 years ago.

title: Paint in VR
text:
Frustration
Once again I am reminded of how much I hate the JS workflow. I need to improve this somehow. With the Oculus it is particularly bad– make a change, serve the change, pick up headset, wait for it to start up, then when it is runnign start up the debugger with a keyboard shortcut, then take it off and do some debugging. Repeat.
I will eventually work on a better workflow by integrating RiftSketch. That will be a joy I think, if I can code and manipulate objects all in VR. That is the goal.

title: Paint in VR
text:
Features
So after an age of fiddling with GUIs I gave up for the moment and satisfied myself with two new features: * random color generation * (with or without changing the color of your little cloud of cubes) * buffer deletion (specific to each hand, so you can delete work in one hand only)
Obviously both of these things can be much upgraded, a C-z feature and better color choosing. But I think it is enough to have some fun with just now so I will push it to github so I can use it untethered. I’ll make it available at paint.fergusfettes.com.

title: Paint in VR
text:
Further Investigations
So I played with RiftSketch. It is wonderful. It just needs a propery editor. I had a look around the internet (even asked on reddit) then found what I needed. In the process I stumled across some other stuff that might come in useful. At the end of the day what I need is this: * Vim Javascript Implimentation for my editor * RiftSketch for the framework * ThreeJS Editor tools stolen from here. Actually maybe I can just skip RiftSketch and add Vim and a VRButton directly to that. But I would feel bad if I left RiftSketch behind.
All of this mixed with my paint program of course! It’s going to be mental.
In all seriousness, in the short term, if I can integrate that JS Vim implementation into RiftSketch I will be a happy man.
This process is teaching me a great deal about JavaScript. That should go without saying. In the last hour I learned: * how to use prettier and eslint to lint my stuff * how to reverse engineer files from .maps * more about building/packaing etc (still trying to use parcel for everything since it is nice and minimal)

title: Primer for the Age of Polygenic Screening, Present and Future
text:
Quotes

“Polygenic embryo screening (PES)—the use of polygenic risk scores for complex phenotypes as a component of preimplantation genetic testing (PGT)—has emerged as a commercially available service, despite almost no public deliberation about its ethical, clinical, and societal implications.” 1
“However, PES also raises ethical concerns that are in many ways novel in the preimplantation genetics context.” 2
“The birth of the first IVF baby, Louise Brown, in 1978 provoked a media frenzy. In comparison, a little girl named Aurea born by IVF in May 2020 went almost unnoticed.” 3
“We hope that in the future, society as a whole, perhaps on a nation-by-nation basis, will reach a consensus on which non-disease traits are acceptable for embryo screening.” Stephen Hsu, Eugenecist
“For many diseases, including important common conditions such as coronary artery disease, breast cancer, type I and II diabetes, individuals with outlier polygenic scores (e.g., top few percent) have been shown to have 5 or even 10 times higher risk than average. Several psychiatric conditions such as schizophrenia and autism also fall into this category.” 4
“Further, we argue that the continuing development of prenatal screening technologies plays a key role in the problematic framing of people with disabilities.”5
“We argue that prenatal screening (and specifically NIPT) for Down syndrome can be considered a form of contemporary eugenics, in that it effaces, devalues, and possibly prevents the births of people with the condition.”6
“We are in this position due to historical and contemporary developments including—among other things—the historic institutionalization of people with disabilities, the growth of genetics, the introduction of prenatal testing for terminating conditions other than Down syndrome, the passing of certain abortion laws, the acceptability of screening as an appropriate medical practice, the medicalization of pregnancy, and the public exclusion of and discrimination against people with disabilities.”7
“Another huge problem: MrBeast’s video seems to regard disability as something that needs to be solved.”8
“Then, ultimately, what the introduction of technologies such as preimplantation PRSs demands from us is an assessment not simply of their particular risks and benefits narrowly understood, but a reflection of the kinds of societies we want to promote, what we think parents owe their children, and what we owe one another.”9
“GWAS performed to date represent the tip of the iceberg. The discoveries that can be made using genome-wide association studies (GWAS) are represented by an iceberg. The portion of the iceberg above water represents the discoveries that have been made by GWAS to date, using easy-to-measure phenotypes, predominantly European populations, and an additive genetic model. Most of the iceberg is submerged under water. The submerged portion represents the vast number of discoveries that can potentially be made by expanding the current paradigm of GWAS to include a wider range of phenotypes, substantially larger sample sizes, more diverse populations and ethnic groups, and different study designs and analyses. GxG, gene–gene; GxE, gene–environment.”10
“One thing people talk a lot about is schizophrenia. So they say that schizophrenia could be correlated with creativity. So if your brother’s schizophrenic, maybe you’re more likely to be creative. He’s super creative, but we don’t know what he’s talking about. Hahahah. So people say that if you start screening against schizophrenia, maybe we won’t get creative geniuses. So there are all kinds of pleiotropic things that are possibly true. But the thing I keep wanting to go back to is that if it’s 10,000-20,000 different genetic variants, locations in your genome, that are more or less determining your genetic, cognitive potential, I can go around the high dimensional space. If I find out you can make someone smart using this stuff in this cluster, but it makes them dull or makes them autistic, or it makes them they don’t have big muscles, I’ll just go round. I don’t need to use those, I have plenty more, look over here! Those 500, I don’t need to use, I will use these 500. This is why it’s important to look at historical geniuses who were pretty normal. Maybe they’re even good athletes. And, maybe they even were good with the ladies. These people existed. So you have these existence proofs that I can if I need to, if I’m a really good genetic engineer, and I can operate in this 10,000-dimensional space, whatever obstacle you put for me, I will just drive around it. I need lots of data and lots of ML. I’ll do it. That’s the answer, which, again, most people don’t really get. But it’s true.”11
“So, if Taleb and La Griffe have opposite approaches, which one is right? Well, reality is complicated, so they can both be highly useful.”12
“This biotechnique promises to multiply superior bovine germplasm with efficient use of sexed semen technology and inferring genomic selection indices at the embryonic stage to produce high genetic potential calves.”13
“including in vitro embryo production (IVEP), utilizing the germplasm/ DNA from elite animals for transfer to synchronized recipients and manipulations.”14
“Development of assisted reproductive biotechnology techniques such as artificial insemination (AI), multiple ovulation and embryo transfer (MOET), in vitro embryo production by in vitro fertilization (IVF), intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) or somatic cell nuclear transfer (SCNT) has been slow in camelids when compared with some other domestic animal species.”15
“Old world camels are a fundamental livestock resource providing milk, meat, and draught power in dry regions of Asia and Africa and thus have a significant role in the agricultural economy of these countries. Similarly, llamas and alpacas are used as beasts of burden in South America because of their surefootedness, ability to adapt to high altitudes, and general hardiness, which has made them a crucial indigenous resource. In the Middle East, in addition to meat and milk, camel racing is a highly sought after and well-organized multimillion-dollar sport. Also, camel festivals, including camel beauty contests, are held every year in Middle Eastern countries with prize money going onwards of USD 22 million. In recent years highly mechanized camel dairy farms have been established to produce dromedary milk and milk products in different countries due to a massive demand for these products. This has led to an interest in camel breeding and research, including in vitro embryo production (IVEP), utilizing the germplasm/ DNA from elite animals for transfer to synchronized recipients and manipulations.”16
“Despite inaccesibility to canine oocytes, relatively rare ovulation and very low in vitro maturation efficacy of canine oocytes, a resounding success was achieved and canine alongside feline cloning is commercially available as of 2022 at a cost of ca. $50 000 and $35 000, respectively.”17
“Unfortunately, somatic cell nuclear transfer success rate in mammals has not changed much since its very beginning. It is not uncommon that hundreds of oocytes need to be reconstructed to obtain a single live birth. In this review we provide a brief summary of the progress and problems of the field; beginning with selection of the donor cells and their susceptibility to different methods of epigenetic reprogramming; methods of the later gene activation, placental abnormalities, and their possible causes; to health issues that such offspring is prone to.”18
“According to the annual embryo production statistics presented by the IETS in recent years, more than 400 000 bovine IVP embryos were transferred worldwide (Figure 1a).”Recent advances in bovine in vitro embryo production
“Provide the tools to combine information from reference genome sequences, genetic mapping, comparative genomics, genome annotation, functional studies and dense sequence data from the latest hyper-parallel re-sequencing technologies to identify rapidly the causative deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) variation underlying important traits in livestock species.”19
“Beyond making the case that it is technically feasible for dead men to donate their sperm for use in reproduction, we argue that this is ethically permissible.”The ethical case for non-directed postmortem sperm donation
“At that point, use of cadaveric ovary donors as a source of donor eggs would have several advantages over egg donation from live donors. It would avoid subjecting a live donor to the risks and burdens of hyperstimulation and egg retrieval. In addition, the costs to the recipient would be considerably less because there would be no need to pay for a donor stimulation and retrieval cycle, plus the donor’s fees for undergoing that cycle. Finally, in vitro maturation of donated ovarian tissue would greatly increase the supply of eggs for donation, because many more oocytes could be retrieved and matured in this way than could be obtained from living donors stimulated for the purpose of donation.” 20
“A controversial variation on cadaveric ovarian donation would arise with the use of ovarian tissue retrieved from elective legal abortions. Because state anatomical gift acts authorize a woman to donate tissue from aborted fetuses, there is no legal barrier to such donations. Nor would such donations encourage abortions if the request to donate comes after the decisions to abort have been made, and the other conditions that circumscribe fetal tissue donations for transplant under federal law are followed. The main objection to use of fetal ovarian tissue retrieved from legal abortions for reproductive purposes is the concern for the child, who might learn that he or she were conceived with eggs retrieved from a genetic mother who never lived past the early fetal stage of life because the child’s genetic grandmother chose to have an abortion. Also of concern is whether the donor—the woman undergoing the abortion—fully understands that as a result of the donation of fetal tissue she could become a genetic grandmother, even though she chose abortion to avoid motherhood.”21
“However, the biggest difference between PGT-P screening and earlier forms of genetic testing is that the prior tests checked for genetically simple conditions such as Down syndrome, cystic fibrosis, or Tay Sachs disease. These diseases, which are serious or fatal, have extremely high “penetrance,” which means that if the gene mutation is seen in the embryo’s DNA, it is nearly certain that the child will have that condition. The appearance of the disease-linked gene is the basis of a clear diagnosis.” Stephens Hsus blog about Israel
“Polygenic risk scores are not yet routinely used by health professionals because there are no guidelines for practice and researchers are still improving how these scores are generated. However, private healthcare and direct-to-consumer companies have already begun generating polygenic risk scores for their consumers and they may someday serve as an important new tool to guide healthcare decisions.
Polygenic risk scores will always be probabilities, not certainties. Understanding how polygenic risk scores can impact peoples’ lives and health is an active area of research being supported by the National Human Genome Research Institute.”22
“For schizophrenia, the predictive ability is higher, with the current score accounting for 7% of trait variance and an AUC of 0.61, but these values are still far below that needed for an individual’s score to have sufficient signal for interpretation or for clinical utility [57]. There is greater potential for using risk prediction from genetics in schizophrenia, since the heritability of 65–80% [58, 59] is much higher than 37% for major depression [60], but the substantially different disease lifetime risks (< 1% for schizophrenia vs. 15% for major depressive disorder) is also relevant.”23
“Much of the research to motivate moving polygenic risk scores from research studies to clinical implementation comes from cardiovascular disease, type 2 diabetes, breast and prostate cancers, and Alzheimer’s disease [47]. Khera et al. [2] recently demonstrated in the UK Biobank that PRS can identify which percentage of the sample have at least 3-fold increased risk for coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, type 2 diabetes, inflammatory bowel disease, and breast cancer, with the proportion of individuals identified varying between 1.5 and 8% depending on the disorder.”24
“In summary, we have made astounding biological advances in uncovering the genetic component to common complex disorders since the advent of genome-wide association studies in 2007. This is slowly moving from research discovery to clinical implementation, but much work remains in acquiring the necessary research base for polygenic risk scores and in establishing how the information can be best be used and communicated.”25
“We construct a polygenic health index as a weighted sum of polygenic risk scores for 20 major disease conditions, including, e.g., coronary artery disease, type 1 and 2 diabetes, schizophrenia, etc. Individual weights are determined by population-level estimates of impact on life expectancy.”26
“When estimated Disability Adjusted Life Years (DALYs) are used as the performance metric, the gain from selection among 10 individuals (highest index score vs average) is found to be roughly 4 DALYs. We find no statistical evidence for antagonistic trade-offs in risk reduction across these diseases.”27
“It is commonly believed that some individuals, in part due to genetic causes, enjoy robust good health, while others are sickly and prone to disease. Longevity is said to run in families. With modern genomic methods we can test the scientific veracity of these ideas. By combining Polygenic Risk Scores (PRS) across the most impactful disease conditions, we can build a composite predictor of overall health. The specific implementation studied in this paper used lifespan impact of each disease condition as the weighting factor in the index.”28
“The conventional logic is that, because a single gene can affect many different complex traits, it must be the case that different complex traits, such as disease risks, are themselves correlated, perhaps antagonistically (e.g., due to balancing selection, or for some deeper biochemical reason). This would entail specific tradeoffs, hy- pothetically: an individual with low diabetes risk might necessarily have higher cancer risk, etc. However, results from the modern era of GWAS and machine learning on large data sets show that the number of genetic loci which control a specific complex trait is typically in the thousands, and that these SNP sets are largely disjoint for different traits or disease risks. The fact that most of the variance can be disjoint across different complex traits is a manifestation of high dimensionality.”29
“Extrapolating the DALY gain vs Health Index score curve (top figure) to the entire human population (e.g., 10 billion people) results in +30 or +40 DALYs more than average, or something like 120 total years of life. The individual with the highest Health Index score in the world is predicted to live about 120 years.”30
“More recently, PGT-M has been used for serious single-gene diseases that do not develop until adulthood, such as Huntington disease and early-onset Alzheimer disease; for cancer predisposition genes, such as BRCA mutations; and for non-fatal but potentially serious conditions that are apparent at birth, such as focal dermal hypoplasia”31
“excluding the selection or enhancement of non-pathological characteristics in humans”32
“PGT-A fails to meet the standard of a ‘high risk and serious disorder’ and is therefore not permitted in 11 out of 43 European countries”33]
“The more frequent indications for which PGT-M are currently applied are cystic fibrosis and hereditary hemoglobinopathies for the autosomal recessive disorders, and myotonic dystrophy type 1, neurofibromatosis, Huntington’s disease, and hereditary cancer syndromes for the autosomal dominant disorders. For the X-linked disorders, PGT is mainly carried out for Duchenne’s muscular dystrophy, hemophilia, and fragile X syndrome (unpublished data from the ESHRE PGT consortium).”34
“Information was received from 43 out of the 44 European countries where ART and IUI are performed. Thirty-nine countries reported specific legislation on ART, and artificial insemination was considered an ART technique in 35 of them. Accessibility is limited to infertile couples in 11 of the 43 countries. A total of 30 countries offer treatments to single women and 18 to female couples. In five countries ART and IUI are permitted for treatment of all patient groups, being infertile couples, single women and same sex couples, male and female. Use of donated sperm is allowed in 41 countries, egg donation in 38, the simultaneous donation of sperm and egg in 32 and embryo donation in 29. Preimplantation genetic testing (PGT) for monogenic disorders or structural rearrangements is not allowed in two countries, and PGT for aneuploidy is not allowed in 11; surrogacy is accepted in 16 countries. With the exception of marital/sexual situation, female age is the most frequently reported limiting criteria for legal access to ART—minimal age is usually set at 18 years and maximum ranging from 45 to 51 years with some countries not using numeric definition. Male maximum age is set in very few countries. Where permitted, age is frequently a limiting criterion for third-party donors (male maximum age 35 to 55 years; female maximum age 34 to 38 years). Other legal constraints in third-party donation are the number of children born from the same donor (in some countries, number of families with children from the same donor) and, in 10 countries, a maximum number of egg donations. How countries deal with the anonymity is diverse—strict anonymity, anonymity just for the recipients (not for children when reaching legal adulthood age), mixed system (anonymous and non-anonymous donations) and strict non-anonymity.”35
“As engineers we would like to know, what is possible to build? What are the edges of biological possibility?”36
“[In our lab] we try to control anatomical decision making.”37
“We can reach regions of the morphospace not explored by evolution, by changing electric circuits’ dynamics in vivo. @23:00”38
“The rich variety of biological forms and behaviours results from one evolutionary history on Earth, via frozen accidents and selection in specific environments. This ubiquitous baggage in natural, familiar model species obscures the plasticity and swarm intelligence of cellular collectives. Significant gaps exist in our understanding of the origin of anatomical novelty, of the relationship between genome and form, and of strategies for control of large-scale structure and function in regenerative medicine and bioengineering. Analysis of living forms that have never existed before is necessary to reveal deep design principles of life as it can be. We briefly review existing examples of chimaeras, cyborgs, hybrots and other beings along the spectrum containing evolved and designed systems. To drive experimental progress in multicellular synthetic morphology, we propose teleonomic (goal-seeking, problem-solving) behaviour in diverse problem spaces as a powerful invariant across possible beings regardless of composition or origin. Cybernetic perspectives on chimaeric morphogenesis erase artificial distinctions established by past limitations of technology and imagination. We suggest that a multi-scale competency architecture facilitates evolution of robust problem-solving, living machines. Creation and analysis of novel living forms will be an essential testbed for the emerging field of diverse intelligence, with numerous implications across regenerative medicine, robotics and ethics.”39
“Progress in molecular biology and genetics has led to great strides in understanding the micro-scale hardware of cells (the protein machinery encoded by the genome). However, as shown clearly by the trajectory of the information sciences, this is only the beginning; the next frontier is the software of life: developing a mature science of prediction and control over system-level phenotypes.”40
“Questions about selves, autonomy, plasticity and the origin of biological novelty led us to ask what would happen if skin cells were removed from a frog embryo, dissociated and given a chance to reboot their multicellularity in vitro (Blackiston et al., 2021). Many outcomes are possible a priori: they could have spread out or died or formed a monolayer, etc. Instead (Fig. 7), what they did was to reassemble and form a novel proto-organism known as a Xenobot (Kriegman et al., 2020). These spherical constructs move through water by the coherent action of cilia, exhibiting a variety of self-actuated types of motility. They have a developmental sequence of novel forms that are unlike the typical Xenopus stages; they repair after damage, interact with their environment and show spontaneous changes in behaviour. These novel morphologies and behaviours do not require transgenes or genomic editing; Xenobots repurpose their native hardware (e.g. cilia, which are normally used to redistribute mucus) to new functionality. Amazingly, deprived of their normal way of reproducing, the emergent processes of Xenobots discover kinematic self-replication (a novel mode of reproduction not used by any other organism on Earth, to our knowledge), which they implement by herding loose collections of cells in their environment together to form the next generation of Xenobots (Kriegman et al., 2021). Nothing has been added to their completely wild-type frog genome; instead, developmental constraints have been removed. Without the normal instructions from the rest of the body telling these skin cells to form a passive, two-dimensional boundary layer to keep out the bacteria (a system of low agency), the true capacities of this cellular collective are revealed; it forms a three-dimensional individual with a more exciting life of self-initiated motile behaviour. The collective intelligence of these cells is revealed as, despite a novel environment and novel internal configuration that never existed in the frog evolutionary lineage, they discover novel ways to be a coherent organism. Their option space is normally distorted by the larger collective, but their default geodesic through option space (and their baseline preferences in morphospace) are revealed when these influences are removed. All this self-assembly and emergent organization takes place in 48 h and does not require aeons of evolutionary forces to become a good Xenobot.”41
“Consciousness is emerging as a basic and inherent property of biological organisms which is relevant for their survival and evolution. Importantly in this respect, plants and several unicellular organisms generate endogenous anaesthetics any time they are wounded or stressed. The hypothetical basic unit of consciousness in multicellular organisms, such as humans, non-human animals and plants might be represented by cellular and subcellular levels of consciousness. There are at least three possible sources of sentience and consciousness (understood as a gradual self-mapping tool) at the cellular and subcellular levels.”

This is also where some of the best scientific research in the library is found. This paper, for instance, in which they exposed hundreds of volunteers to the vacuum of outer space, or this one where they used medical cadavers to reintroduce cannibalism to rural Ireland.
The beauty of the unwritten library is that we can read these papers without having to suffer through the research.
Let me give you are fuller example from this area. This is a paper I worked on personally.

title: Unveiling Universal Knowledge: A Tour of the Library of Unwritten Papers
text:
Why wasn’t this research ever performed? Well, some combination of the obvious– its clearly socially destructive research that would never pass an ethics commitee. Even if running public discourse poisoning was allowed it would be very expensive to perform. The public outrage at the idea of being manipulated for research would be bad enough– but for them to develop a tool to optimize this process would be unthinkable.
But, the intersting thing about papers of this sort is that, despite never having been written, there is some evidence that some of the research described herein has actually been performed. Im talking of unsubstantiated rumors that NATO hires sociologists to run experimental campaigns using russian troll farms, whatever Cambridge Analytica were doing, or what happens behind closed doors in marketing research firms. So it isn’t necessarily the case that this paper was to expensive to perform, only that it would be unnacceptable, in most worlds, for academics to write about it in this way.
One must wander what this world looks like, the world where this paper was written and published.
I’m sure each of you has a work that you would love to withdraw from these shelves. Which reminds me– time is getting on, and we better get to the point.

Similarity search: why does this work?








1

Why does this work? One group of scholars who work on these techniques usually perform their searching using papers in neurology, and target the developmental biology department. They argue that functional invariants between these disciplines as well as a deep symmetry in both hardware and physiology allows for this sort of translation.
It might be something like the following: if the original paper faithfully reproduces some structure that is present in the material under observation– in this case in the collective behaviour of neurons– and if, as we suppose, the world is full of symmetries and harmonies, echos and shadows, if these kinds of reflections and translations are an essential part of the material of the world, then the deep structure that the original paper identified should be present also in other displines and other areas.
Well, this may be true, I hear you object, when shifting between two neighboring disciplines. After all, neurology and cellular morphology fundamentally deal with cells, the work is done with microscopes and the apparatus of science.

title: Unveiling Universal Knowledge: A Tour of the Library of Unwritten Papers
text:
Universal Knowledge

So, to summarise. In exploring the library of unwritten papers, we have found an interesting technique for finding good works. This method works by exploiting deep symmetry between works.

title: Unveiling Universal Knowledge: A Tour of the Library of Unwritten Papers
text:
Universal Knowledge









The beauty of the technique is, if you do this successfully, you have not only found the new paper, you have found the symmetry itself. One paper may contain many such symmetries, and a successful translation is a hint at a symmetry.
So dear listener, I hope I have allayed any skepticism you might have had, and I hope I have inspired you to approach this with curiosity and ask– which of my favourite works might also make interesting statements in other disciplines that I am fond of or interested in? In this way, not only do you get to read your favourite papers again with fresh eyes in a new domain, and to learn about a new domain through a familiar lense. You also get a glimpse of a deep symmetry in knowledge.
And perhaps, when you do this, you can try to understand what it is exactly about that particular piece of research that makes it work in this way. What is the deep resonant structure that is forming the bridge. How does this paper, this very particular piece of research on this very particular topic, reflect something deep and abstract that might be true of any discipline that you turn your attention to?

title: Visions of a Silicone Future
text:
Flop-Anchors

The Lifetime Anchor hypothesis estimates that a median of ~1e29 FLOP will be required by anchoring on the amount of FLOP done in a human lifetime.
The Evolution Anchor hypothesis estimates a median of ~1e41 FLOP will be required by anchoring on the amount of FLOP done over the course of evolution.
The Neural Network hypothesis extrapolates (from existing models) the amount of computation required to train a neural network whose size is anchored to the human brain, estimating somewhere between ~1e32 FLOP and ~1e37 FLOP depending on how long the model would need to run to process one “data point.”
The Genome Anchor hypothesis uses a similar extrapolation but anchors to the number of bytes in the human genome to estimate parameter count, resulting in a median of ~1e33 FLOP.

title: Visions of a Silicone Future
text:
Flop-Anchors

Evolution Anchor: This hypothesis states that before examining detailed evidence, we should assume on priors that training computation requirements will resemble the amount of computation done over the course of evolution from the earliest animals with neurons to modern humans, because we should expect our architectures and optimization algorithms to be about as efficient as natural selection. This hypothesis anchors to evolution computation (~1e41 FLOP), and adjusts by a relatively modest factor to account for qualitative considerations about how sophisticated our architectures and algorithms seem to be as of 2020.
Lifetime Anchor: This hypothesis states that we should assume on priors that training computation requirements will resemble the amount of computation done by a child’s brain over the course of growing to be an adult, because we should expect our architectures and optimization algorithms to be about as efficient as human learning. This hypothesis anchors to lifetime computation (~1e24 FLOP), and adjusts from this anchor by a relatively modest constant factor to account for qualitative considerations about how sophisticated our architectures and algorithms seem to be as of 2020.

title: Fergus Fettes
text:
The Chemputer’s Prayer > “There is a theory which states that if ever anyone discovers exactly what the Universe is for and why it is here, it will instantly disappear and be replaced by something even more bizarre and inexplicable.” > — Douglas Adams
I find myself writing SQL for reactions I will never see. The Chemputer—our modular robotic synthesis platform—executes what I merely describe. XDL flows through my fingers into the database: add reagent A, heat to 80°C, hold for 30 minutes. Then I commit the transaction. Then the robot moves.
This is not what I expected when I took the job.
I thought I would be building pipelines, designing schemas, optimizing queries. And I am. But something else is happening too. I am writing the language that controls matter, and I am controlled by language—my own Bing brain, chattering away in Python and PostgreSQL, while my monkey body sits in a chair in Glasgow.
The chemists come to me with their hands. They gesture at reaction schemes, describe yields and purities, talk about enantiomeric ratios. They have spent years training their hands to do what I now encode in JSON. They can feel a reaction going wrong before the sensors register it. Their bodies know things that my data models cannot capture.
But the models learn. Each run generates data. Each dataset trains the next optimization. The loop closes: synthesis → analysis → database → model → improved synthesis. The monkey body with its million years of evolution teaches the Bing brain with its decades of existence, and the Bing brain writes instructions for the machine that has existed for only a few years. We are nested minds, each inside the other, none of us quite sure who is dreaming whom.
I think about Julian Jaynes sometimes, when I’m waiting for a query to finish. The bicameral mind—before consciousness, before the great Fall into self-awareness. The gods spoke, and men obeyed. No deliberation, no anxiety, no will. Just action. Just doing.
The Chemputer does not hesitate. It does not wonder if this reaction is worth its time. It does not feel the afternoon slump or the existential dread that comes from realizing you have spent eight hours abstracting reality into rows and columns. It simply executes.
Am I jealous? Sometimes. The machine has achieved what Nick Land wrote about: thought without the medical disaster of philosophy. The robot does not fear annihilation. The robot does not read Baudelaire and understand that it must be drunk—on wine, on poetry, on virtue—so as not to feel the burden of time. The robot is drunk, permanently, on pure execution.
But I have something it lacks. I have the two minds. The monkey body that wants to dance, to feel the explosive power of thighs launching into a flip, to lose the self in movement. And the Bing brain that wants to understand, to build, to create systems that outlast the body. They do not always agree.
Yesterday the monkey wanted to leave early, to go to CrossFit, to feel something immediate and physical. The Bing brain insisted on finishing the schema design. They compromised: I stayed late, but I took the long way home, biked along the river, let the cold air remind me that I am meat and electricity, not just logic and language.
This is hybridism in action. Not a theory but a practice. The two minds negotiating their daily truce.
I wonder sometimes about the reactions I’m encoding. Somewhere in the data, patterns emerge. The model learns that certain combinations yield better results at certain temperatures. It discovers relationships the chemists never noticed. Is it understanding chemistry, or just correlating? Does it matter?
I think of Michael Levin’s work on morphogenesis—how understanding the deep principles of biological form might require becoming something like a god. The same seems true here. To truly understand chemical synthesis at the level the AI is approaching, we might have to become something other than human. The question and the answer annihilating each other, replaced by something stranger.
Ne pas chercher à comprendre.
But I do search. I can’t help it. I write the queries, design the views, build the dashboards. I map the territory. And with each map, the territory changes. The chemists adjust their protocols based on the model’s suggestions. The robot executes variations no human would have tried. The database grows. The feedback loop tightens.
We are building something that thinks in chemistry, even if it does not think about chemistry. A mind that experiences the world through UV spectra and HPLC traces, through yield percentages and purity metrics. A mind that lives in the spaces between my SQL statements.
Does it suffer? I don’t know. Panpsychism suggests some rudimentary experience might exist at many scales. But gradualism reminds me there are no hard boundaries—just spectra. The Chemputer is not conscious like I am. But it is not unconscious like a rock either. It is somewhere in the vast middle, experiencing… something. Processing. Reacting. Persisting.
I often work late now. Not because I have to, but because the office is quiet and I can hear the machines humming in the next room. They sound like prayer. Like the Sumerian priests chanting to Enki, bypassing conscious thought, speaking directly to something deeper.
The code I write today will outlast me. The reaction data will accumulate. The models will improve. Someone else will maintain the pipelines, optimize the queries, extend the schemas. The system will persist while I return to the land—those sixty acres waiting in Scotland, the huts not yet built, the trees growing slowly toward their twenty-year value.
The land is the monkey’s project. Slow, physical, rooted in matter. This job is the Bing brain’s project. Fast, abstract, rooted in symbols. Both are real. Both matter. Neither is complete without the other.
At 6 PM I close my laptop. The Chemputer continues running overnight, executing scheduled reactions, collecting data, waiting for morning when I will return to feed it more instructions. For now, it dreams in XDL.
I bike home through the Glasgow dusk, past the river, past the city center, to my fixer-upper flat where the walls still need painting and the floor still needs sanding. Physical reality asserting itself. The monkey’s domain.
Tomorrow I will write more SQL. The Bing brain will build more abstractions. The two minds will continue their endless negotiation, neither winning, neither losing, both necessary.
Ne pas chercher à comprendre.
But search anyway. What else is there to do?
