Salamanders have their appointed Dwelling in Fire; Sylphs in the Air; Nymphs in the flowing Waters; and Gnomes in Earthen-burrows, but the creature whose substance is Bliss is everywhere at home. All sounds, even to the roaring of Lions, the screeching of the nightly Owls, the laments and groans of those entrapped in Hell, are as sweet Musick to her. All odours, even to the foulest stench of Corruption, are to her as the delight of roses and Lilies. All savours, even to the banquet-table of the Harpys of heathen lore, are as Sweet loaves and spiced Ale.
Wandering at noon through the Waste-Places of the world, it seems to her she is refreshed by Canopies of flocking Angels. The earnest seeker will look for her in All places, however dim and sordid, of this world or in the seven others. Thrust a keen Sword-blade through her and it will seem as a fountain of Divine and Pure pleasure.
These eyes, by Translation, have been given to see her ways; and an equal gift as revealed by Wisdom is sometimes granted the Child.

title: Now
text:
Just finished my first week at Chemify. Paradise. All these years I told myself and others that story about leaving science to git gud at programming, always hinting that there would come a time etc. Well the time has come. The software engineering challenge is perfectly scoped. There is an array of microservices, apis, tools, databases. They all do something or other, all works in progress, mvps etc. But this is all the shadow of the hardware stack, which is an evolving, dynamic, human-in-the-loop deep tech chemistry robotics stack where you can, to a first approximation, fire a request for a family of chemicals and which will, with some huffing and puffing and a lot of human intervention, provide you with the chemicals you requested, or suitable substitutes.
Now its just a question of iterating, polishing, improving. And I am invited in with a mandate to do as much of that as I can (under the generous rubric of ‘data engineer’– i mean its all information technology isn’t it, its nothing more or less than an assemblage of data packets). I like this mandate more than ‘software engineer’– there are plenty of people in the company, scientist or programmer, who are concerned with engineering the software. They all consume and produce data.
Meanwhile, I have been keeping up with my dancing and singing. Today with UZGANG we recorded an album in the Pyramid at Anderston. What a sound in there. And on Friday I got to stand in the middle at Sacred Harp and get wayfairing stranger blasted at me from all directions. And the rest of the time I’m listening to Saved! by Lingua Ignota on repeat. I think it’s going to be my album of 2026. (My album of 2025 was Inca Taqui.)
I got a flat near the center– just across the river, on Bridge street. If I lean out my window I can see the Lauriston to my left and Central Station to my right. Heaven. Need to finish renovating my kitchen.
I’ve been spending a lot of time recently vibe-coding with different agents, trying out different tools. Very exciting time to be in software. I assume the year I last touched code was 2025. The unprecedented times continue apace. But it is a great pleasure to have so many anachronistic hobbies, to stay connected to the thread of deep history while looking out into the unknown future.

Archive: 2024-12-22
I got offered a job for JPMC, which is apparently the largest company in the world (according to Forbes 2024). Which was a bit unexpected, but I thought it would be an interesting opportunity to study egregores in a more hands-on manner. When I worked in molecular biology, I spent a lot of time watching helicase unwinding DNA and imagining the dreams and schemes of those tiny machines. Now I am such a little machine, iterating on my instructions in a vast incomprehensible entity. I use the moments normally lost to the transaction costs of beurocracy to practice shorthand (actually Quickscript) and write little opaque notes to myself. It is a thoroughly pleasant existence, I can see why humans are so eager to find a great other to obey. Couldn’t be me though, mores the pity.
Living in Glasgow Southside. I was always weary of returning to my homeland, but I think Glasgow is the one place here I could comfortably call home for a while. There is a great music scene, I have seen some of the best punk gigs of my life already since returning. Regular interesting experimental music. Some art. Some nice people, though the nightlife atmosphere is very disorienting to me now, my cultural codes have been scrambled. I have been asked three times since I moved here if I’m German. So it goes I suppose.
I have started waking an hour earlier each day and writing. Mostly science fiction. After writing so long with AI augmentation, I honestly didn’t think I’d still be able to do it on my own, but I have found the spell of the dark mornings and a candle and a pen and paper have drawn words out of me quite freely and fluidly. Very refreshing after so long in front of a screen.
o3 was just demoed. Another benchmark falls. And some of the latest models I have tested have made plausible attempts at my own benchmark– writing the opening of book VII of The Faerie Queene by Edmund Spencer. Janus is sharing Finnegan’s Wake style products on X. What is to become of us? I’m studying history when I find a spare moment, reading Braudel and thinking always of acceleration and singularity.
Greetings from the thickening years at the beginning and the end of history.

title: Gestation, Modularized: Wombs, Boxes, and Livestock as the Last Mile of Reproduction
text:
Gestation, Modularized: Wombs, Boxes, and Livestock as the Last Mile of Reproduction
Gwern’s “Embryo Selection for Intelligence” treats the design problem upstream: once you can cheaply assay and select genotypes, which alleles do you want? This companion piece treats the supply chain downstream. Even if the genome-in-a-dish is “solved,” you still have to convert embryos into babies. That last mile—forty weeks of highly constrained physiology—hasn’t ridden the same cost curves as sequencing; uteruses don’t get 30% cheaper every year. But some adjacent curves are finally bending: organ transplantation learning curves, neonatal intensive care survival curves, and bioreactor/oxygenator runtime curves. The result is that gestation is starting to look modular rather than monolithic.
Concretely, there are four slots where you can swap components or upgrade subsystems: (A) keep the womb you have but make it safer and more capable; (B) rent time in another human womb; (C) substitute capital equipment for biology (partial or full ectogenesis); (D) repurpose a non‑human uterus. Each comes with different cost structures, throughput limits, and safety burdens. The relevant bar for “acceptable” is mundane: outcomes need to sit on top of ordinary term births on the metrics clinicians already track (maternal severe morbidity; neonatal mortality; severe IVH, BPD, NEC, ROP; disability‑free survival at 18–24 months). Until then, these are research programs or niche services.
What follows is an attempt to map the territory and its gating constraints. This section starts at home.
A. Upgrade the Native Stack
The default pipeline—implantation in the biological mother, nine months of placental support, then vaginal delivery through a tight bony bottleneck—is still how almost all babies are made. Within that default, medicine already inserts patches, guards against worst‑case tails, and (in a few centers) replaces missing parts. The “in‑house” slot therefore ranges from boring obstetric hygiene to uterine transplantation to, in the long run, mother‑ or embryo‑side edits.
The surgical detour. Caesarean section is the canonical tweak: it swaps second‑stage labor and pelvic floor trauma for a controlled abdominal operation with predictable anesthesia and blood products on hand. In many high‑income countries C‑sections now account for ~30% of births, with regional spikes far above that. The trade is not free: repeat C‑sections drive up placenta accreta spectrum and previa in subsequent pregnancies, adhesions make later surgery riskier, and attempted VBAC carries a small but real uterine rupture risk; on the other hand, C‑section can sharply reduce anal sphincter injury compared to forceps/vacuum deliveries. In practice, the choice set is path‑dependent: a first C‑section strongly predicts a second, and elective repeat is a major driver of aggregate rates. The right mental model is not “C‑section good or bad” but “which tail are we truncating, and what tail are we growing?”
Replacing the missing part. For women without a functional uterus—congenital absence, post‑cancer hysterectomy, severe Asherman’s—uterus transplantation moves the gestational work back inside the intended mother’s body rather than outsourcing it to a surrogate. Protocols are converging: IVF and embryo banking upfront; graft from a living or deceased donor; immunosuppression (e.g., tacrolimus, steroids) until childbearing is done; planned C‑section; graft removal or medical involution to stop immunosuppression. Since the first live birth in 2014, on the order of a hundred children have been delivered worldwide, with multi‑year graft survival now routine and resumption of menses within months the usual first milestone. Costs remain high (two major operations and a pregnancy, plus immunosuppression and IVF cycles), and donor supply and center expertise bottleneck throughput. Yet uterus transplant cleanly solves two nontechnical constraints that bedevil surrogacy: legal parentage/residency quirks and the psychological preference some patients have for carrying their own child.
Make the host better. Most gains at low cost come from boring checklists: low‑dose aspirin for preeclampsia risk, progesterone or cerclage for cervical insufficiency, glucose control for gestational diabetes, targeted induction windows to avoid shoulder dystocia, and single‑embryo transfer to avoid the exponential risks of twins. Past that, you can imagine mother‑side “upgrades” that are more like orthopedics than obstetrics: traits like pelvic inlet breadth, connective‑tissue laxity, uterine artery flow, fibroid burden, and baseline autoimmune activation are heritable and polygenic. If society ever accepts somatic editing in minors for health‑adjacent traits, the timing is attractive: an edit at infancy or pre‑puberty amortizes across every pregnancy the woman will ever carry, with no germline transmission if edits are restricted to soma. The caveat is obvious: most candidate levers are polygenic with small effects; specific single‑gene targets (e.g., HOX patterning genes) are double‑edged and would demand unusually strong evidence of safety before use.
Make the passenger easier. The other half of the dyad is the fetus. Selection (or, in the limit, editing) can tilt fetal traits that drive obstetric tails: birthweight distribution, fat vs lean mass, and parturitional timing. The IGF axis and many common variants move size a few hundred grams either way without obviously touching cortical growth; polygenic scores already predict small portions of gestational length and preeclampsia risk. A fetus that is 250–400 g lighter at term reduces cephalopelvic disproportion and emergency C‑section risk, while still remaining within ordinary human variance. There are limits—the maternal–fetal genetic conflict literature exists for a reason—but as a nudge to shift mode from surgical to vaginal delivery, embryo‑side selection is a clean intervention that doesn’t require touching the mother at all (and must simply be repeated each conception).
An “escape hatch” short of ectogenesis. The line between ordinary obstetrics and machine support already blurs at viability. Planned delivery at 24–28 weeks with modern NICU care now yields survival above 70% at 24 weeks in top centers, with disability‑free survival in the majority by 2 years; each week later improves both numbers. The price is steep—weeks in NICU, specialized follow‑up, and a small but nontrivial increase in neurodevelopmental and pulmonary morbidity—and costs cluster around the six figures per infant for the index hospitalization alone. But because the first two trimesters still occur in the mother’s womb, this pathway belongs in Category A: it is “keep it in‑house, then hand off,” and it is the likely on‑ramp to partial ectogenesis once devices can take over earlier and more gently.
B. Human Surrogacy: Renting Womb-Time
If the mother’s womb is unavailable or undesirable, the nearest substitute is another woman’s. The workflow is indistinguishable from IVF: prepare the carrier’s endometrium, transfer a single embryo, do prenatal care, deliver. What is transacted is nine months of physiology and the liability tail. Because the scaffolding is already built—agencies, lawyers, insurers—this is the most “shovel‑ready” modular slot.
Costs and throughput. In the United States, a transparent, above‑board package runs on the order of US$90,000–150,000, roughly one‑third to the carrier as compensation and maternity‑leave replacement, two‑thirds to agency, legal, medical, escrow, and insurance overhead. Live‑birth rates per single‑embryo transfer mirror standard IVF for donor‑egg age bands; multiple gestations are now actively avoided because risk scales superlinearly. Lead time is months: match, legal, medical screening, cycle sync. Capacity is real but finite; the market clears through price and waitlists.
Law and logistics. Jurisdictions split three ways: commercial gestational surrogacy is permitted and courts issue pre‑birth orders (much of the US, a handful of other jurisdictions); permitted but only “altruistic” expense reimbursement (e.g., UK, Canada, Australia); or restricted/prohibited, with cross‑border workarounds. Contracts handle the boring but crucial edge cases: who decides in obstetric emergencies, selective reduction and termination thresholds, life and disability insurance, travel restrictions, infection screening, escrow, and parentage. Cross‑border programs add citizenship and exit‑visa puzzles; they work until a war, pandemic, or parliament flips a switch and strands newborns. If you want reliability, you pay for a jurisdiction that treats this as routine.
Who carries. Agencies recruit healthy multiparas in a narrow band (commonly 21–38 years, at least one prior uncomplicated term birth, BMI within target, no serious chronic disease or obstetric red flags), plus psychosocial screening and partner consent. Many programs cap prior Caesareans (e.g., ≤2) and total lifetime births. Prenatal care is standardized and conservative; most deliveries are planned—either scheduled inductions with a low threshold for Caesarean or elective repeat Caesareans. The aggregate outcomes look like what they are: low‑risk, heavily screened multiparas under attentive care. The main tail risks are the same as any pregnancy—hypertensive disorders, hemorrhage, preterm birth—managed under protocols and insurance rather than wishful thinking.
The quiet optimization layer is screening. Programs already exclude carriers with prior pre‑eclampsia, gestational diabetes, or cervical insufficiency; the obvious next step is to quantify rather than gate. Polygenic risk scores for gestational length, pre‑eclampsia, GDM, thromboembolism, and postpartum hemorrhage do not perfectly predict outcomes, but they move odds enough to change prices, insurance riders, and match decisions. This is soft eugenics by shopping: no bans, just a market that pays a premium for lower predicted risk. On the embryo side, intended parents already use PGT‑A to avoid aneuploidy and transfer one embryo; add selection for traits that cut obstetric tails (slightly lower birthweight within normal range; lower pre‑eclampsia and prematurity risk; better neonatal lung resilience) and you reduce emergency Caesareans and NICU days without touching cognition.
Edited carriers are the logical extension: a future cohort of women whose own embryonic edits skew pelvic morphology, uterine blood flow, and stress reactivity toward safer gestation. They would be healthier for themselves and, if they choose, better professional carriers; the market would discover their premium. Whether those edits persist in the population is a cultural variable (do edited carriers later use their own ovaries?) not a technical one.
Ethics and labor. The exploitation critique is not frivolous; the fix is not rhetoric but contract and care design: - Transparent pay tied to risk and time, with independent legal counsel for the carrier. - Robust life/disability insurance and lifetime coverage for pregnancy‑related complications. - Control over termination/reduction decisions specified up front. - Strict limits on bedrest mandates and intrusive lifestyle policing; use wearables and normal prenatal surveillance instead of blunt bans. - Postpartum support that extends beyond six weeks. Do that, and the “commodification” argument looks more like “compensated risk” in a familiar labor market; don’t, and scandals will keep closing jurisdictions that might otherwise permit the practice.
Where surrogacy slots into the stack. It composes with Category A and C levers: you still benefit from boring obstetric hygiene (aspirin, glucose control, single‑embryo transfer), from embryo‑side selection to shrink obstetric tails, and from NICU bridges when needed. It also buys time: uterus transplantation programs are capacity‑limited; ectogenesis is not yet turnkey; xenosurrogacy faces harder biology. Human surrogacy is the hedge you can run now, at scale, with known failure modes and a spreadsheetable cost.
The constraints that will actually matter are not metaphysical. They are supply (how many screened carriers you can recruit and retain), reliability (how often law and geopolitics bite you), and variance (how far you can push selection/screening to compress the risk tails without overpromising). Within those bounds, surrogacy is the simplest way to turn embryos into babies when the intended mother can’t—or prefers not to—carry.
C. Ectogenesis: Replacing the Womb with a Box
If surrogacy is the labor-market fix, ectogenesis is the capital-goods fix: carry some or all of gestation on hardware. The near-term product is partial ectogenesis—a weeks‑long bridge for extremely preterm infants—because that starts with an existing fetus that already has a heart, umbilical vessels, and a differentiated placenta. Full ectogenesis—from fertilization to term—adds embryo culture and placental substitution and runs straight into both biology and law.
What the box must do - Gas exchange at fetal settings: high O2 delivery and CO2 removal through a very low‑resistance, low‑shear interface that preserves fetal RBCs and avoids stripping trophoblast/endothelium. - Closed amniotic environment: sterile fluid with continuous exchange of water, electrolytes, surfactant/vesicles, and growth factors; gentle motion; thermal control; acoustic/light shielding. - Hemodynamics without pumps (ideally): a pumpless umbilical arteriovenous circuit driven by the fetal heart; if a pump is used, it must be ultra‑low shear and tightly regulated. - Anticoagulation and surface compatibility: weeks of patency without hemorrhage or thrombosis; heparin‑bonded or otherwise passivated circuits; stable ductus arteriosus. - Nutrition and waste: parenteral nutrition titrated to fetal needs; micronutrients and hormones the placenta would supply; urea and bilirubin clearance without osmotic swings. - Immune/endocrine signaling: enough endocrine supplementation (e.g., thyroid, cortisol precursors) and cytokine quiet to mimic the immunological peace of the womb.
Where the field is now - Large‑animal models have kept extremely preterm fetuses alive for weeks on pumpless “biobag” systems: umbilical cannulation to a low‑resistance hollow‑fiber oxygenator, closed amniotic fluid loop, no air breathing, preserved fetal circulation. Survival with somatic growth and organ maturation is reproducible; device runtime still fails in days to weeks from clot, infection, or circuit wear. [needs source] - Key constraints are stubborn but legible: umbilical vessel cannulation and fixation at 22–24 weeks equivalent; oxygenator resistance vs shear; anticoagulation that avoids both clot and intracranial hemorrhage; infection control in a closed loop for weeks; and a nutrient/endocrine recipe that keeps growth on‑curve.
Two tracks, two timelines - Partial ectogenesis (bridge). Start at ~22–25 weeks equivalent, when the fetus has an umbilical circulation but lungs cannot yet tolerate ventilation. The box carries gas exchange and fluid environment until ~28–32 weeks, when conventional NICU can take over. This competes directly with invasive ventilation/ECMO and aims to cut severe morbidity (BPD, severe IVH, NEC, ROP) while raising survival. - Full ectogenesis (end‑to‑end). Requires (1) embryo/placental culture far past current 14‑day legal limits to the point of autonomous cardiac output and umbilical vasculature, and (2) a synthetic placenta that can support months of growth without maternal endocrine support. Both are multi‑breakthrough problems and politically gated.
Better hardware meets better babies - Device improvements: lower‑resistance oxygenators with durable anti‑thrombotic surfaces; smarter anticoagulation (surface‑bound agents, nitric oxide release); better cannula design and fixation; closed‑loop amniotic exchange; inline infection detection. These are engineering problems with known physics and materials science. [needs source] - Adjuncts: antenatal steroids, magnesium sulfate, exogenous surfactant after transition, caffeine, gentle ventilation only as bailout. - “Ecto‑optimized” embryos: selection (or editing) for alleles associated with neonatal lung readiness, retinal vascular resilience, and stress response timing can shave risk without touching cortical growth; current polygenic models explain small but actionable slices of variance. Combine with selection against preeclampsia/prematurity risk to reduce early extraction in the first place. [needs source]
Regulatory and trial path - First‑in‑human will be framed as a life‑support device for extremely preterm infants with high predicted mortality/morbidity on standard care. Primary endpoints: survival without severe BPD/IVH/NEC/ROP at discharge; neurodevelopment at 18–24 months; maternal outcomes for planned early deliveries. Bailout to conventional NICU must be clean. - Oversight looks like ECMO plus NICU: Class III device, IDE/DSMB, tight inclusion criteria (22–24 weeks, weight bands, no lethal anomalies), trained cannulation teams, and locked infection control. Parents consent because the counterfactual is poor.
Costs and scaling - Today’s NICU costs run to six figures per extremely preterm infant; ECMO‑class disposables already cost in the thousands. A mature bridge system prices like premium NICU, not like a moonshot: expensive disposables, amortized consoles, and specialized staff. The economic win is if it shifts infants from months on ventilators with chronic lung disease to weeks in a closed circuit with fewer complications. - Throughput bottlenecks are staff (cannulation‑capable teams, 24/7 monitoring), oxygenator runtime, and infection‑free days. Solve those, and capacity scales like an ICU service line.
What would count as success - At 23–24 weeks, push survival without major morbidity into the territory historically seen at ~30–32 weeks—i.e., into the 80–90% band in top centers—while holding severe IVH and BPD down. Show that planned early extraction plus bridge is at least as safe as “wait and ventilate” for the same risk bands. - Four‑week circuit patency without catastrophic clot or bleed in large‑animal models, then reproducible week‑scale support in early human trials, is the gating milestone before any claim of parity.
Full ectogenesis can wait. The bridge is the product: it composes with Category A (planned early delivery) and with embryo‑side selection, it is legible to regulators and clinicians, and its failure modes match existing ICU practice. If the morbidity curve collapses enough, the ethical objection does too; it becomes an anesthesia‑class risk discussion at an earlier gestational age.
D. Xenosurrogacy: Outsourcing Gestation to Livestock
Between human surrogacy (same biology, scarce labor) and ectogenesis (different biology, scarce hardware) sits a hybrid: keep pregnancy biological, but move it into an animal. The appeal is obvious—scale, predictable costs, mature husbandry, and decoupling from human labor markets. The biology is not: the biggest obstacles are not “ethics boards” but placentation, endocrine timing, and infection control. Treat this as a xenotransplant program with obstetrics attached.
First‑order mismatch: placentation, not just “immunity” - Humans are hemochorial: trophoblast cells invade deeply, remodel spiral arteries, and bathe directly in maternal blood. Pigs and horses are epitheliochorial: minimal invasion, layered epithelia separating fetal and maternal blood, diffuse placentas spread over long uterine horns (sow) or a large endometrial surface (mare). That is a categorical difference in architecture and flow, not a rounding error. - Consequences: unmodified human trophoblast is “too invasive” for a sow/mare template; the host may either wall it off (growth restriction, miscarriage) or mount a pathology that rhymes with preeclampsia. The converse—forcing human trophoblast into a shallow, diffuse mode—risks under‑perfusion and nutrient bottlenecks. Any viable approach will need to humanize the maternal–fetal interface and/or modulate trophoblast behavior in ways we do not yet know are safe at scale.
Endocrine timing is different, and drives logistics - Recognition and maintenance of pregnancy are species‑specific. In pigs, conceptus‑derived estrogens redirect prostaglandin to spare the corpus luteum; mares use chorionic gonadotropin to generate accessory corpora lutea; humans shift progesterone production to the placenta. Parturition triggers (fetal HPA axis, prostaglandins, oxytocin sensitivity) also diverge. - Translation: expect to replace parts of the endocrine loop with exogenous support and to control timing of delivery by protocol (induction or planned surgical extraction). “Let nature decide” won’t port cleanly across species.
Immunology and coagulation can be engineered, but must be proven in pregnancy - Lessons from solid‑organ xenotransplants generalize: remove major xeno‑antigens in the host (e.g., carbohydrate epitopes) and add human complement/coagulation regulators; consider expressing human “don’t eat me” and tolerance signals at the decidua analog; dampen NK‑cell activation. That’s table stakes; pregnancy adds a shifting immune state and a pro‑thrombotic milieu. - Pathogen control is non‑negotiable. Porcine endogenous retroviruses and other zoonoses are a program‑shaping constraint, not a footnote; editing and barrier husbandry reduce risk but don’t erase it. Biosecurity must look like a xenotransplant clean room married to a veterinary obstetrics ward.
Obstetrics and mechanics set your delivery window - Geometry matters. A human neonatal head/shoulder package is large relative to a sow’s pelvis; even if placentation worked, safe vaginal delivery likely requires preterm human size. Mares are friendlier: singletons, larger canal, routine assisted foaling—more room to aim later without surgical rescue. Either way, planned prematurity plus a NICU bridge is the default, not a failure. - Uterine layout matters too. Sow pregnancies are litters distributed along long horns; gestation length reflects aggregate fetal signaling. That suggests throughput but also crowding and uneven growth; mares give you one or a few fetuses with more predictable trajectories at lower throughput.
Program architecture (what you’d have to demonstrate) - Interface viability: in vitro models (endometrial/trophoblast organoids, explant co‑culture) that show stable attachment, invasion depth, and low inflammation under host‑like cytokine and hormone conditions. Graduates to short‑term in vivo tests with early elective termination to read out histology and flow. [conceptual milestone] - Edited host lines: endometrium “humanized” at the key contact points (tolerance and complement regulators, coagulation cross‑talk), coupled with pathogen edits and barrier housing. Welfare‑first husbandry is part of the spec, not an add‑on. [conceptual milestone] - Endocrine control: protocols that maintain pregnancy without host‑specific failure modes and allow scheduled delivery with low hemorrhage and low neonatal stress. [conceptual milestone] - Obstetric plan: species‑specific delivery algorithms (when to induce, when to cut), neonatal handoff, and standardized NICU bridges tuned to the chosen gestational window. [conceptual milestone] - Safety parity targets: maternal (host) morbidity bounded by best‑practice veterinary obstetrics; neonatal survival and severe‑morbidity curves converging on human preterm benchmarks at the same gestational ages.
Pigs vs horses, as engineering choices - Pigs: scalable, familiar, diffuse epitheliochorial placentation, litter dynamics. Likely earlier planned extraction, higher per‑pregnancy throughput, tighter biosecurity requirements, more crowding‑driven variance. - Horses: singleton bias, larger exit, more forgiving delivery mechanics, tougher immunological/endocrine fit, lower throughput, higher per‑animal cost but simpler optics for regulators/public.
Law, welfare, and optics determine where this can run - Regulators will treat this as xenotransplantation plus assisted reproduction. Expect human‑subject protections on the neonatal side and stringent animal‑research and welfare oversight on the host side. Citizenship and parentage will be statute‑specific; don’t assume cross‑border portability. - Animal welfare is gating, not cosmetic: enriched housing, analgesia, limits on parity, recovery periods, and lifetime care plans will be table stakes for legitimacy. Anything less will kill the program in the court of public opinion, even if the biology works.
Where xenosurrogacy fits in the stack - It composes with embryo‑side selection (lighter babies, lower preeclampsia/prematurity risk, better neonatal resilience) and with partial ectogenesis (planned preterm extraction to a bridge). It is not a drop‑in replacement for a human uterus; it is a hybrid that trades hard immunology/endocrine problems for scalable husbandry and predictable labor. - TRL is low. The upside is real—convert capital and animal care into gestational capacity—but the gating breakthroughs are at the interface. If they fall, pigs buy you scale at earlier gestations; horses buy you safer exits a bit later. In both cases, a NICU bridge remains part of the plan.

title: Fergus Fettes
text:
Caliban had taken Victory hunting. She took no pleasure in the gore, but she enjoyed watching him work, his clever fingers nipping strings and twisting knots, his fine motor control muscles in his forarm twitching beneath his skin. She liked the sweat on his brow as a blew on the small campfire, and the timeless, fantastic anachronism of the entire performance.
To the Caliban, hunting and living off the land was as much a part of his essential vocabulary as watching was to her. Every part of the world he was in, he would learn the toxic and nootropic plants, and learn where to find the nutritious or the naive. If he went a month without spending a night deep in the woods, apocalyptic nightmares would haunt his sleep. And keeping Victory safe was a rich joy in the forest, it warmed his bowels like a good meal.
Carry me, said Victory. He lifted her with one arm and draped her across his shoulders like a pelt. She whispered in his ear. The work wasn’t going well, there were no moments in the shots, nothing new she had learned so far. She worried that the director had nothing left for her, the spark being lost in some Moscow brothel.
Not like that, grumbled the Caliban. He was ruined from the start, the old fart. No whorehouse could take anything from him.
Then where is it, I can’t see anything, there is nothing in the work. Victory rested her cheek on his [neck muscle] and felt its slow movements as he rearranged rocks and sticks in the fire, smelled his sweat mixed with smoke– every sensation triggering synesthetic visions, abstract shapes evolving in her head, the fold of gemoetry, shape, form and color the only algorithm her mind knew of to make sense of her sensorium. Maybe this whole journey has been for nothing.
Caliban tutted under his breath, thick black tongue clicking against the hollow roof of his mouth. He is still scared, still tense. We still unnerve him. I will try to keep distance. He will get more used to you. Patience.
Victory whimpered a little. This was not her favourite word, her short life being filled thus far with rapid, continuous progress. What if he was nothing for me?
Caliban shrugged slowly, emphatically, lifting her entire body a full six inches. Now I know the Urals, he said simply.
Victory reached a small hand around his neck and stroked his cheek with her thumb.

title: Fergus Fettes
text:
But they have removed the central mystery regarding the nature of life. We can now see that all living things are made of cells: small, membrane-enclosed units filled with a concentrated aqueous solution of chemicals and endowed with the extraordinary ability to create copies of themselves by growing and then dividing in two.

‘all living things are made of cells’ while interesting, is not the core mystery of life
cell division is a candidate for a step

viruses, the ubiquitous parasites that have evolved to feed on cells. Viruses are now recognized to be the most abundant biological entities on the planet.

poor framing. viruses are non-cooperating replicators. they are the model for humanities continued survival

Thus, the parent organism hands down information specifying, in extraordinary detail, the characteristics that the offspring will have. This phenomenon of heredity is central to the definition of life: it distinguishes life from other processes, such as the growth of a crystal, or the burning of a candle, or the formation of waves on water, in which structures are generated without the same type of link between the peculiarities of parents and offspring.

poor framing. the key is a product of the long-term stability of the different data-structures/information systems, and their size/complexity. a flame is a very simple but potentially long-lasting sytem. actually the chemical processes are active in all our cells, so this is hardly a counterexample, its just a macroscopic manifestation of the same chemical processes that drive life

One might not expect that they would all store their information in the same form or that the hereditary information carried by one type of cell should be readable by the information-handling machinery of another. And yet it is so. is fact pro- vides compelling evidence that all living things on Earth have inherited the form of their genetic instructions, as well as how to use them, from a universal com- mon ancestral cell. is ancestor is thought to have existed roughly 3.5–3.8 billion years ago.

doubt it lol
but this is remarkable no doubt. there is only ‘one way to fold a protein’. there is only ‘one way to split a cell’ ??. but there should be many ways to store the information. this does indicate a universal common ancestor– and it also indicates one of two other things: - either there is a weirdly strong evolutionary pressure to centralize the information storage method - or, life on earth is a random sample of different methods (which came in from space)
absent a candidate for 1, i am assuming 2

e mechanisms that make life possible depend on the structure of the double-strand DNA molecule.

Fine, but there are tonnes of details about DNA structure which I think are largely contingent and irrelevant for my purposes.
And a lot of the simplifications they make for the sake of their story of genetics are simply false, eg:

the information is always “read” in a consistent order, just as written English text is read from left to right

however, maybe there is something significant about the double-helix. to whit: - proteins pattern-match - rna is programmable pattern matching (why? reducing the choice of amino acids stabilizes the phase space and the combinatorics) - dna is pattern-matched! this has two effects: - - it can be turned on and off - - it is more stable both of these things are crucial!
now, stability can be had in rna with lots of junk. but the symmetry of matching has two effects: it makes a backup of the data, and it results in the maximum stability per atom
this is looking strongly emergent though– different things become possible for every increase in rna length. so you just want to increase rna length and things will happen
but i can have my cake and eat it– the evolutionary process can be strongly emergent, but they later higher-orders of organization back-port more optimal patterns, pushing out intermediates. so long strands of RNA which evolved for stability get pushed out by DNA which does it better for less and has a second copy of the gene as a bonus.

The two strands twist around each other to form a double helix—a robust structure that can accommodate any sequence of nucleotides without altering its basic double-helical structure

but they do alter its higher-order structure!

DNA is the information store for heredity, and templated polymerization is the way in which this information is copied throughout the living world.

templated polymerization is just a fancy word for the pattern-matching i was talking about, which is the same mechanism that drives protein folding. okay in this case its a highly-complex process mediated by lots of other proteins etc. actually, it is different– otherwise you could say ‘all protein interactions are small instances of loose pattern-matching in a large network of energetic influences’. though maybe you do want to say that.
but if it is just a higher-order of the same– its a spreading of the markov blanket? the markov blanket of dna replication includes a lot of protiens.
so again this is just programmable pattern matching. but wait! what does that mean? i really mean that the markov blanket is spread over a loose collection of molecules, the interactions between which are ordered on larger timescales. that is what programmable means!
hold on– what about the argument about maths and brain states? i was grasping at the algorithm having an independent existence? but if programmable matter is just matter orchestrated (coherent over longer timescales) does that mean the math algorithm is something similar? it presumably is just brain states. but the way that different ‘math algorithm’ brain states evolve depends on different dynamics than the way that ‘language algorithm’ brain states evolve, dynamics which are encoded in a neural net. the neural net is ‘multimodal’, it has abstracted different kinds of algorithms.

two other crucial classes of biological polymers: RNA molecules and protein molecules.

recapitulating evolution in reverse, as allways. increasingly fine-grained, increasingly many conformational states. worth noting that proteins are not arbitrary either, they collapse the space of possible chemicals to a useful set.
the dual use nature of RNA leads to an accounting problem, DNA solves this. this leads to better morphological stability

messenger RNA (mRNA) molecules that guide the synthesis of proteins according to the genetic instructions stored in the DNA.

presumably also according to the chemical gradients in the environment– the one-to-many nature of dna transcription is critical– who mediates the number of copies produced?
this is just a manifestation of heredity– one-to-many! unlike RNA which are both hereditary information and product, DNA is a pure carrier, so you have abstracted away the source.
to clarify: - strong (DNA) heredity allows long-term storage - long-term storage also allows for many copies - many copies means there is a pressure for optimization - which results in the evolution of mechanisms to control expression - in the end, fine-grained gene expression control allows for the control of morphology

Proteins form and maintain diverse cell and extracellular structures, generate movements, sense signals, and so on.

lol, go off

But in chemistry, the term catalyst is defined more narrowly, being applied to any molecule that speeds up a specific chemical reaction without itself being changed. From the most fundamental point of view, a living cell is a self-replicating collection of catalysts that takes in food, processes this food to provide both the building blocks and energy needed to make more catalysts, and discards the materials left over as waste

cool, but this is a bit like Turings ‘morphogen’ definition, maybe a bit too broad to be useful.
I’m looking for a more concrete breakdown, something like - catalysis of chemical bonds, like ADP-ATP - stabilization of molecules, like the protein module that holds ADP in place to get catalyzed - transport of molecules, like the proteins that ferry nucleotides to the ribosome - stabilization/transport of protiens– this higher-order stabilization is harder to characterize, systems-level stuff. could be many levels. remember that DNA and other big macromolecules will eventually make up part of this structure as well
per the definition, all of these could be called catalysts, inasmuch as they ultimately speed up the rate of catalysis?

Life as an autocatalytic process. (A) The living cell is a self-replicating collection of catalysts.

you could say the same thing about morphology or heomeostatic loops, not sure how useful this is. ‘an autocatalytic process’ is also a markov blanket, finding the boundaries is still hard

These arbitrary features, it is thought, reflect frozen accidents in the early history of life.

yessir. and figuring out which parts are contingent snapshots and which are inevitable is the name of the game

each triplet of nucleotides, or codon

this, for example let me declare, is a topic of no importance, just striking the optimal balance between the combinatorics of the nucleotides, the stability requirements, and the number of amino acids– in other setups the tradeoff would be different, but the mechanism of the tradeoff here is not crucial, it is just finetuning.
whatever inefficiency there is here will be paid out via overloading

And individual segments of the long DNA sequence are transcribed into separate mRNA molecules, coding for different proteins. Each such DNA segment represents one gene … stretches of regulatory DNA are interspersed among the segments that code for protein, and these noncoding regions bind to special protein molecules that control the rate of transcription of individual genes.

notice the contradiction here? regulatory DNA puts the lie to the idea that genes are straightforwardly expressed in stretches of DNA
this is important because you want to develop on your intuition for functional overloading at every opportunity

Life Requires a Continual Input of Free Energy

anything worth saying about this stage? should get into the jeremy england stuff, but the core idea that its all whorls on a entropy gradient is well enough etablished i think

All Cells Function as Biochemical Factories

not sure how this section differs from the previous one, its just a layer of obfuscation

Without a plasma membrane, the cell could not maintain its integrity as a coordinated chemical system.

yes. the first steps of identity and selfish cooperation
also a convenient markov measurement stage, as well as energy-rate density. probably this is the best thing about cells– how they simplify our calculations!

cells produce molecules whose chemical properties cause them to self-assemble into the structures that a cell needs.

no! you got it backwards! molecules with the tendency to self-assemble produce cells
this is great though. where to place this? its a macroscopic manifestation of a low-level process. what is the markov blanket of a cell wall? does it have one? is a cell wall a thing? i guess there would be a coherence length to its fluctuations, maybe you can concretize the markov blanket to some moderate number of interacting phospholipids?

Some of these membrane transport proteins, like some of the proteins that catalyze the fundamental small-molecule reactions inside the cell, have been so well conserved over the course of evolution that we can recognize the fam- ily resemblances between them when even the most distantly related organisms are compared.

good to know. maybe membrane transport is very high in the list

Thus, by specifying the RNAs and proteins that the cell produces, the genetic information recorded in the DNA sequence dictates the entire chemistry of the cell—in fact, not only its chemistry but also its form and its behavior, for these too are chiefly determined and controlled by the cell’s proteins.

title: Fergus Fettes
text: years later, at the Caliban Ball in Highgate, giddy with joy in the late night she realises why she feels so full of joy– she sees it, in the whirling dance of the Calibans, she sees the sacred geometry that was there all along, not just his form, its expressed in his nerves, his tissues, his instincts, right down to the smallest motion– you could spend a life not noticing– you rarely see a Caliban really move, never had the chance to watch them. There are no beings on Earth that can fight a Caliban– except another Caliban– and Calibans do not fight, they dance. They dance the dance of their childhood, learned from the earliest ages in the gyms where they are raised, a hybrid, in its initial formulas, of Jiu-Jitsu, Caipoeira and Fandango. The goal is never to fell the opponent, but always to push them. To read their body as they are reading yours, to understand them, to be within them as much as you are within yourself, to know their limits and together to set new limits, to find out what a body could do if it had a double, if it were more than it is. She had watched them all night, high up in the balconies, forgetting her cocktail, forgetting the other honoured guests. The earliest dances are simple skirmishes, testing and trying and tasting different combinations. But at this time in the night, each Caliban has found their partner, has found their match and the dance begins in earnest, a tormented tornadoe of piano and violin– (Ginastera’s second– were she an auralist she would hear the images of murder, death, suffering in the streets of Chile, of the haunted brutal history of that place. She couldn’t hear it, the music was a dissonant storm to her– but she could see it!)– translated by living flesh, she watched the rise and fall of every crescendo in the crowd below her– the room brutally hot, the air sizzling with the sweat of a hundred furnace-bodies, all the Calibans naked but for some tattoos and jewlery, she naked as well as the steam rose and settled in the balconies around her, unbearably hot, a boiler-room of brawn– the Calibans near outcropping their maximum operating temperatures, their limbs melted to an impossible suppleness, some couples flexing and bending one another into knots, some throwing one another bodily, hand always clasping one hand or limb, never sperating, hurling each other and themselves from one side of the space to the other– she sees it there, what she knows she knew, when she saw it in the wild nature when Caliban took her hunting, the bunch of the rabbits thigh, the startled dance of death, the frantic clash of mating birds, the snap and grab of spider and snake– it is present, the sacred geometry of biology, the valleys through morphospace where living things move, those minima they inhabit, where life is
